loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary B. is currently in the business of selling fruits like pears, jack fruits, oranges, and many others. She is requesting a loan to stock more pears and jack fruits to sell. Mary is 31 years old and is married; her husband is a teacher. She has two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock more pears and jack fruits

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en:
Bonifacia E. is from the town of Talibon. She is 51 years old. Bonifacia is married. To make a living, Bonifacia owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Bonifacia has been involved in fishing for several years already. She hopes to be to sustain her family's financial needs.

Bonifacia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bonifacia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Bonifacia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Bonifacia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing important materials for the wedding

loans.name: Brigelda

texts.en:
Brigelda A. is from the town of Talibon. She is 57 years old. Brigelda is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Brigelda owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish and also crabs at the market. Brigelda has been engaged in her business for over 20 years.

Brigelda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brigelda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Brigelda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Brigelda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Liloba Plus Group

texts.en:
Liloba Plus is a group of 15 owners of small businesses chaired by Maguy Y.. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Maguy Y. sells smoked fish. She has been in business since 1987. She has acquired solid experience selling smoked fish. Since she joined one of Hope’s groups called “Liloba Plus” meaning “Word” in English, her business has been significantly reinforced through seven loans she has received from MFI HOPE DRC and repaid them properly. 

Through her sales, Maguy makes about US$ 100 per week. She plans to use the next loan to purchase some more bags of smoked fish and sell them at a profit in order to increase her income. She dreams one day of opening a food shop. Maguy is 58 years old, married and a mother of six children between the ages of 22 and 35; only two of them attend school. The rest of the children are independent. In spite of her age, Maguy likes selling because it gives her the opportunity to make contact with many different people, and once they become permanent customers she is able to offer them quality products at a better price.

loans.use: purchasing some more bags of smoked fish to resell at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores E. is from the town of Talibon. She is 33 years old. Dolores is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Dolores owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish and crabs at the market. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over 15 years. 

Dolores joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the third loan taken out by Dolores from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Tièssiri  (Le Courage) Group

texts.fr:
Tièssiri est un regroupement de  dix femmes mariées  du quartier Madina Koura de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) qui   vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies, avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins  5  enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, le  bois de chauffe, les habillements, du poisson fumé et plusieurs autres articles. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 ans. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Sali G. qui est la présidente du groupe, vend du bois de chauffe, des habits,  du poisson fumé et divers autres produits.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe auprès des  paysans producteurs, des habits à Bobo Dioulaso  et Bamako, quant au poisson fumé, dans les marchés des localités environnantes de Koutiala. 
Elle vend le bois de chauffe en détail et au comptant à la maison, les habits et le poisson fumé sont vendus au grand marché de Koutiala à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que les membres du groupe Tièssiri comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 90 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Sali G. compte réaliser 110 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement du prêt, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille (scolarisation et enfants et santé). 
Elles ambitionnent renforcer leur partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour qu’il n’ait plus de rupture de stock.
texts.en:
Tièssiri regroups ten married women from the Madina Koura borough of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), who live in large traditional extended families along with their husbands, children and other relatives. They are on average 35 years old and have at least five children. This group of women practices the retail commerce of products such as firewood, clothing, smoked fish and others. Two years ago, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit loan association to increase the level of their activities. They are now requesting a fourth group loan, having fully reimbursed all preceding loans. Sali G. is the president of the group; she sells firewood, clothing, smoked fish and various other products. She wants to use her loan to buy cartloads of firewood from local workers, clothes from Bobo Dioulaso and Bamako, and smoked fish from village markets in the vicinity of Koutiala. She retails the firewood from her home for cash, and sells clothing and smoked fish at Koutiala’s main market, to a wide and varied customer base. Whereas the other members of the Tièssiri group hope to achieve average earnings of 90,000 FCFA each for this loan cycle, Sali G. hopes her profits will reach 110,000 FCFA. In addition to reimbursing the loan, the group members use part of their earnings to meet habitual family expenses (tuition, children and healthcare). Their ambition is to strengthen their partnership with Soro Yiriwaso, to avoid future supply shortages.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Tenning

texts.fr:
TENNING T. est une femme de 58 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de 03 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par des proches. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WALIDANE depuis le 22 octobre 2007. 

Elle fait de la restauration depuis plus de 5 ans. Comme activité secondaire elle fait de l'embouche ovine. 

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter 15 sacs de riz et des provisions pour son restaurant. Acheter également 10 mouton pour faire de l'embouche.

Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et d'augmenter son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
TENNING T. is a 58- year-old woman who is married and a mother to six children. She also has three other children who were entrusted in her care by relatives. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of WALIDANE since October 22, 2007. She has been in the restaurant business for over five years. As a secondary activity, she also fattens sheep. With her new loan, she will buy 15 bags of rice and grocery supplies for her restaurant. She also plans to buy 10 sheep to fatten. Her goal is to help improve her family’s living conditions and increase her savings.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies to expand her restaurant, and to buy 10 sheep for fattening

loans.name: Psaumes Plus Group

texts.en:
“Psaumes Plus” is a group of 17 owners of small businesses chaired by Jean Claude. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRC to grow their businesses.

Jean Claude started his business in 1987 with a capital of $15 selling pairs of slippers. After he went bankrupt from 2004 to 2006 because of theft, he decided to open a general boutique that he operates today. With hard work and determination, his business prospered. Jean Claude is happy to be part of one of Hope’s groups.  He has already received six times the loans and his business has been reinforced through the loan he received. Jean Claude intends with the next loan to diversify his business by adding a cassava leaves pounder and other items to reinforce the inventory of his business in order to increase the profit. He is 48 years old, married and has four children between the ages of 1 and 27 of whom one goes to school. Currently, Jean Claude makes the profit of about $90 per week. His dream is someday to expand his business in different markets in Kinshasa. Jean Claude’s business is located in the western area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To purchase canned goods and other miscellaneous items for his shop

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday V.  is currently in the business of selling charcoal out of her home and is requesting a loan to stock more charcoal to sell.  Sunday is 47 years old and is married to a husband who is a farmer. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday D.  is currently in the business of selling maize flour, fish and rice at the market and is requesting a loan to stock some bags of beans and pulses to sell.  Sunday is 47 years old and is married to a husband who is a watchman. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock some bags of beans and pulses to sell

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda P. is currently in the business of selling bread, tea and fried fish in the evening along the market street and is requesting a loan to stock more fish and tea materials such as sugar, tea leaves, etc.  Matilda is 45 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more fish and tea materials such as sugar, tea leaves, etc.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen A.  is currently in the business of selling beans, maize flour, and pulses at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and sweet potatoes to sell.  Hellen is 51 years old and is widowed.   She has 7 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and sweet potatoes to sell

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.en:
Committed first and foremost to his family, Kahramon works very hard at his ranching business. He has his own herd of cattle with which he works day after day to earn a living to support his dear wife and two children. 

Just as every business requires investment, Kahramon's business now needs to add some young bulls, which will be raised and sold. For this reason, he once again has turned to IMON International to obtain a loan to acquire the cattle and, in this way, serve to help improve the standard of living of his beloved family.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase of young cattle

loans.name: Kilangira Deevelopment Group-Mukono

texts.en:
S. Florence is a 45 year old widow who knows her back would be against the wall had she not taken the initiative to blaze a business trail 7 years ago. She began as a worker in a stone quarry. Prior to that she was still trying to come to grips with the death of her husband who was by then the sole bread winner for the family. 

In the following years she was living by her wits. Sensing that Florence was having difficulty providing for her family, a close friend of hers persuaded her to bear a hand in any business activity that could extricate her out of her predicament. It is then that this cheerful mother of 8 tried stone quarrying. With time she changed her priorities and began a restaurant and hotel business in Kilangira-Mukono. Her stone quarry business however is something she still has reins over. She has never looked back. In a week, she makes profits that sum up to 100,000 shillings and with this loan, she is looking at buying more utensils, i.e., cutlery, for her restaurant and equipment for her stone quarrying business.

loans.use: utensils for restaurant; equipment for stone quarry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing of foodstuffs, sim-cards and prepaid mobile phone cards

loans.name: Maguette

texts.fr:
Madame Maguette DIOP est âgée de 39 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de 04 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par des proches. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WALIDANE depuis le 19 novembre 2004 et a 11 fois de suite reçu de crédit.

Elle développe un petit commerce de friperie, de chaussures et de parfums. Comme activité secondaire elle fait de l'embouche ovine.

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter de la friperie, des chaussures, des parfums et deux moutons.

Elle a comme objectif de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille par exemple acheter de la nourriture et payer des frais médicaux.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maguette DIOP is 39 years old. She is married and a mother to five children. She also has four other children entrusted in her care by relatives. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of WALIDANE since November 19, 2004 and has been granted 11 consecutive loans. She has a small business selling used clothing, shoes and perfumes. She also fattens sheep as a sideline. Her new loan will enable her to buy used clothes, shoes, perfumes, and two sheep. Her goal is to help improve her family’s living conditions by providing food and covering medical expenses.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothes, shoes and perfumes, and two sheep

loans.name: Adolat

texts.en:
Education is the most important inheritance that Adolat and her husband can give to their three dear children. They are both very responsible parents, and they work very hard at farming, so that they can give their children the opportunity to finish school – an opportunity they never had due to poor finances. 

This happy mother has been working in agriculture since getting married and, with the unconditional help of her husband, she buys and sells cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs. Even so, she now finds herself with more expenses, and she would like a loan in order to increase their capital by increasing their number of cattle.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Music Retailer Group

texts.en:
Thomas T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Music Retailer. Thomas is 41 years old, married and has seven children who range from 3 to 19 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to a lack of financial support.

For 3 years, he has been selling DVD discs in Redlight Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more DVD discs.

His dream is to improve his business and continue to educate his children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, F. is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more DVD discs.

loans.name: Die

texts.fr:
Madame DIE T. est âgée de 42 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WALIDANE depuis novembre 2004. Elle a 06 fois de suite reçu de crédit et a toujours remboursé régulièrement.

Elle fait un commerce de tissus depuis plus de trois ans.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter 150.000 francs CFA de tissus wax, 150.000 francs CFA de tissus Khartoum et 200.000 francs de tissus Thioupe.

Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge des besoins familiaux, par exemple la nourriture, la santé et le payement de la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. DIE T. is 42 years old, married and the mother of 5 dependent children. She has been a member of the WALIDANE Banc Villageois since November, 2004. She has had 6 consecutive loans and has always repaid regularly. She has operated a fabric business for more than three years. With her new loan she is going to buy 150,000 francs CFA worth of wax fabric, 150,000 francs CFA of Khartoum fabric and 200,000 francs CFA of Thioupe fabric. Her goal is to contribute to the support of her family, for example, the food, health care and paying for the children’s tuition.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wax, Khartoum and Thioupe fabrics

loans.name: Salomat

texts.en:
A. Salomat is 50-year-old lady. Salomat and her husband, who is in entrepreneur currently, have been married for about 25 years and raised three wonderful children. Salomat has been running her own small business for 11 years already, she has a trading place at the market for selling shampoos, detergents, tooth-paste and brushes and other items. Salomat is very friendly and polite which allows her to have the clientele. Now she is requesting  a loan of $1500 US dollars. Salomat is planning to use the loan for purchasing more goods for selling thus increasing the range of the products. She thanks everybody who decides to support her.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
K. Yusuf is a 47 year old man. He is married and has two children. Yusuf owns a grocery store and provides for his family with the revenue generated by the grocery store. He is requesting a loan of $1000 US to increase his stock. Yusuf is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame FATOU D. est une femme de 39 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de 02 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par des proches. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WALIDANE depuis le 19 novembre 2004.

Elle fait un petit commerce de friperies, de chaussures et de parfums. Elle pratique cette activité depuis bientôt trois ans.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter des friperie pour 250.000 francs CFA, des chaussures pour 130.000 francs CFA et des parfums pour 100.000 francs CFA. Elle paye des frais de transport à raison de 20.000 franc CFA.

Son objectif est de participer financièrement à la prise en charge des besoins familiaux tout en augmentant son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou D. is a 39-year-old woman who is married and the mother of five children. She also supports two other children who are entrusted to her by friends or relatives. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of WALIDANE since November 19, 2004. She has a small business involving used clothing, shoes, and perfumes. She has had this business for nearly three years. With her new loan, Fatou is going to buy second-hand clothing for 250,000 francs CFA, some shoes for 130,000 francs, and perfumes 100,000 francs. She is covering the cost of transport at 20,000 francs. Her goal is to help support her family financially while increasing her savings at the same time.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying used clothing, shoes, and some perfrumes

loans.name: Mashhura

texts.en:
M. Mashhura is 42 years old. She is married and the loving mother of 4 children. She is a hard-working woman struggling to feed her children by selling the national fabrics for the national dresses. Mashhura, together with her daughter (pictured), has the trading place in the central local market of Kanibadam town. 

She is trying to have a wide range of goods to meet the requirements of her customers and to satisfy the needs of the clients with different levels of income. Mashhura, being a devoted mother, is doing her best to give her children a good education and to make them happy. Today Mashhura feels that with more working capital her business could generate more income, so she is asking for a loan of 5500 Tajikistani Somoni to jumpstart the business and raise the family's standard of living.

loans.use: Purchasing new fabrics to expand store inventory

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en:
O. Mohira is 49 years old. She and her husband have raised four children. Mohira makes the embroidery of the national skull-cap for men and women. She is really hard working. Mohira gets up very early and goes to bed very late. When she is not embroidering the skull-caps, Mohira is selling them in the local market. Mohira is planning to expand her business. She requests $1500 USD. Mohira is planning to spend the loan on fabrics for embroidering the national skull-cap. Mohira has received two preivous loans from IMON and has demonstrated that she is a reliable client. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fabrics for embroidering the national skull-cap

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
S. Nasiba is 46 years old. She is married. She uses all the money she makes to care for her three children and to provide for their education. Nasiba has 13 years of experience preparing and selling dried apricots. She always makes very good use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. She is also very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Today Nasiba is requesting $1500 USD. She is going to use the loan to purchase dried apricots so that she can process them, thereby increasing the range of her products. Nasiba expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase dried apricots

loans.name: Zulaikho

texts.en:
Zulaikho is a 49 year old married mother of three children. Her husband is a taxi driever. Zulaikho started her business in 2001 in order to support her family. All year she sells fruits and vegetables that she buys from local farmers. With the loan of 5000 TJS from Kiva, she plans to increase the range of her products and to buy apples, pears, grapes, peaches, and other fruits. Zulaikho strives to give her children a better life, including supporting them through a high level of education. With her business, she has been able to supply the community with fresh fruits and also provide for her family. Zulaikho is a well-spoken, friendly business woman who is worthy of the support of Kiva partners.   
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Tp increase selection of fruits

loans.name: Sope Cheikh Sadieye Mbaye Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de Solidarité SOPE CHEIKH SADIEYE M. est créé le 05 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 14 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même quartier et partagent la même confession religieuse. Elles ont formé leur groupe par affinité et voisinage. 

Madame FATIM M. debout à l'extrême droite sur la photo, vêtue de grand boubou vert, est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 59 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de ses 3 petits fils. 

Elle fait de l'artisanat. (de la broderie, du crochet, couture de pagnes et fabrique de colliers en perles) Elle mène cette activité depuis qu'elle était jeune fille.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter des fils et des tissus pour la broderie et acheter également des perles en couleur et du fil en nylon pour fabriquer ses colliers. 

Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et prendre en charge sa progéniture.
texts.en:
The Sope Cheick Sadieye M. solidarity group was created 5 December 2007. It is made up of women from the same neighbourhood with the same religious faith. They got together through personal affinities and as neighbours. Mrs. Fatim M. is the person responsible for the group. She is standing at the far right of the picture, wearing a large green “boubou” (dress). She is 59 years of age, married and the mother of three children. She also takes care of her three grandsons. She is a craftsperson: embroidery, crochet, a tailor of “pagnes” (colorful West-African clothing fabric), and creator of bead necklaces. She has been performing these activities since she was a young girl. With her new loan she will buy thread and fabric for embroidery work, and also coloured beads and nylon string to create her necklaces. Her objective is to bolster her savings and take care of her dependants.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies to develop her craftwork.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is married to an accountant with whom she has two children. Both her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members.  She owns a stall at her home in Nalukolongo selling bananas. She buys bunches of bananas from delivery vans which get them from villages. 

Edith wants to use this loan of 2,000,000/= to buy more bunches of bananas. She has been in this banana business for over ten years. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale and works seven days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and the rainy season. She is aspiring of  going directly to farmers and hopes to start selling wholesale only.

Edith decided to work with MCDT because of low interest charged.    She resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and school  fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is married to an accountant with whom she has four children. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall at  selling tomatoes and other vegetables like onions and cabbages. She has been in this business for two years. She buys baskets of tomatoes from Kalerwe market and uses public transport to and from Kalerwe. 

Eva wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of bananas and onions. Besides this tomatoes business she also owns poultry farm  at her home. She sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. She works seven days a week. Her major business  challenges includes thieves and seasonality. 

Eva is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and hopes to start going directly to farmers. Eva decided to work with MCDT because of low interest rates charged and  good customer care.  Eva resides in and owns a house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Elisha

texts.en:
Elisha K. N. is a man of forty-two, married to Rhoda N. who sells groceries, and together they have three children, Elisha is an electrician and has a shop in Eldoret town where he repairs electrical goods. He has been in this business for eight years now. Also he has employed two staff members who work for him in his shop; he earns an income of thirty thousand shillings monthly.

This will be Elisha's eighth loan with KADET. He repays all his loans well and without any difficulty. With this loan he is going to buy electrical accessories like switches, tube lights, and also use part of the money to complete building his fish pond in Kapchumba in Eldoret.

With the income he gets, he plans to complete building his residential house which is half way built, and in future he plans to expand his business and provide basic needs for his family like food, shelter, education, etc.

loans.use: To buy electrical accessories like sockets, tubes, switches, etc.

loans.name: Palmier Plus Group

texts.en:
Jean Jacques N., aged 37, is the leader of the Community Bank named “Palmier Plus”, which is composed of 22 members united in solidarity to receive loans from MFI (micro-finance institution) HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses. Jean Jacques started his business in 1998 selling fresh foods. He operates a drugstore in the western part of Kinshasa. 

Jean Jaques is a loyal client of MFI HOPE RDC who has already received five different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to buy more medicine needed by his customers in his area to resell with the aim of increasing his profits. Each day, his business brings in a profit of US$ 10. 

His ambition is to expand his business by opening other drugstores in different places. Jean Jacques is married and has three children, who are aged between 3 and 12 years old. Two of them go to school.

loans.use: to purchase medicine needed by his customers

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Marth

texts.en: Marth J. is currently in the business of selling various ornaments such as earrings, necklaces, weaving materials, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials to sell.  Math is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

loans.use: Stock more weaving materials to sell

loans.name: Sufuriana

texts.en: Sufuriana K. is currently in the business of selling bags of groundnuts and 'simsim' (sesame seeds) at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize  and millet to sell.  Sufuriana is 36 years old and is married to a husband who is a police officer. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real shop in order to increase her profits.

loans.use: Stock bags of maize  and millet to sell

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is 42 years old and has 8 children who range from 6-24 years of age. Four of her children are in school, while the other children are not in school because she can’t afford to pay their school fees.  Her husband is handicapped, yet he still practices farming.  

Dative sells foodstuffs such as sorghum.  She keeps these food items in large sacks in her store to create space for more items.  She has done this business for 16 years.  She wants a loan to buy more sorghum to add to her inventory.  With a greater inventory she believes she will be able to sell larger amounts and generate more income.

loans.use: Purchasing sorghum for sale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther K. is currently in the business of selling pairs of trousers, bedsheets and dresses at the market and is requesting a loan to stock pairs of shoes and sandals to sell.  Esther is 20 years old and is single.   With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: Stock pairs of shoes and sandals to sell

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty is married to a manager with whom she has four children. All her children are in school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members.   She owns a retail shop in Kazo Angola. She sells to all categories of people, retail. 

Resty buys her merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala City and uses public transport to and from Kikuubo.  She goes shopping once a week.  She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and jerrycans of cooking oil.  She has been in this business for years. 

Besides this grocery business Resty also sells second-hand shoes at her shop.  Resty works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include the rainy season because she lives in a place which is prone to floods, and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo to her home in Kazo Angola. She is aspiring of educating her children up to university and owning a wholesale shop  

Resty joined MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap,  and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Joyeux Luttins Plus Group

texts.en:
Héritier Z., aged 22 and single, is the president of the Community Bank “Joyeux Luttins Plus”, which is composed of 16 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Héritier runs a cellphone booth and is a money changer. He has been in business since 2009. He manages his cellphone booth in his area located east of the city of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of IMF HOPE RDC who has already received five different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to buy prepaid cards to resell with the aim of increasing his profits. Each week, his business brings in a profit of US$ 25. His dream is to open a general store and purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: to reinforce his working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.en:
Jeannette is 41 years old.  She has twelve children that range from the age of 12 months to 24 years.  Eight of her children are in school while the rest are not yet of school age. Her husband sells food crops.

Jeannette sells fabrics and has been in this business for 12 years.  She needs a loan to expand her business.  She plans to buy more fabrics in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: Buying more fabrics

loans.name: Elizebeth

texts.en: Elizebeth M. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, sorghum, and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and pulses to sell.  Elizebeth is 40 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 5 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock bags of rice and pulses to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia R. is currently in the business of selling charcoal, bread, and dried fish at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Cecilia is 41 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has four children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Baax Yaye Group

texts.fr:
La groupe de solidarité BAAX YAYE est créé le 05 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 12 femmes issues du même quartier. Elles ont formé leur groupe par voisinage et par même centre d'intérêt. 

Madame ANTA BOUYA S., ) l'extrême droite de sur la photo, vêtue de grand boubou orange parsemé d'étoiles blanches est la responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 57 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Elle a aussi la charge de sa belle fille et de sa petit fille. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de colliers et de bijoux en perles de couleurs. C'est elle même qui fabrique les colliers avant de les revendre en faisant du porte à porte. Elle pratique cette activité depuis au moins 20 ans.

Son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter beaucoup de perles en couleurs pour fabriquer plus de colliers et de bijoux afin de réaliser des bénéfices plus importants. 

Elle a comme objectif d'augmenter son niveau d'épargne et assurer la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
The Baax Yaye solidarity group was created on 5th December 2007. It is made up of 12 women from the same neighborhood, who are neighbors and/or have the same interests. Mrs. Anta Bouya S., who is on the extreme right of the photo and dressed in a large orange "boubou" (African dress) sprinkled with white stars, is in charge of the group. She is 57 years old, married and mother to six children. She also has responsibility for her daughter-in-law and granddaughter. She has a small business selling necklaces and jewelry made out of colored beads. She makes the necklaces herself before retailing them on a door-to-door basis. She has been carrying out this business for at least 20 years. Her new loan will allow her to buy a large quantity of colored beads in order to make up more necklaces and other jewelry and make a more significant profit. Her aim is to boost her savings and provide for her family's needs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase colored beads

loans.name: Celina

texts.en: Celina S. is currently in the business of selling local brew and beer in the bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Celina is 57 years old and is married with a husband that is a security guard. She has 6 children and 4 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her bar

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice C. is currently in the business of selling beans, pulses, and rice at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish and tomatoes to sell.  Alice is 39 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for her children.

loans.use: Stock dried fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Julienne

texts.en:
Julienne is 25 years old and has 3 children who range from the age of 2-12 years.  All of the children are in school apart from the youngest.  Her husband is a businessman.

Julienne has a shop which contains sugar, Vaseline, salt, etc. She has done this business for 12 years and she aims to have a wholesale shop. She is requesting a loan to increase the number of items she sells in her store.

loans.use: Purchasing items to sell in her store

loans.name: Patricie

texts.en:
Patricie is a hard working mother of 15 children who are between 11-30 years old.  She is 53 years old and a widow.  Three of her children are in school and the other ones do not attend school because she cannot afford their school fees.

Patricie sells sorghum and sorghum beer and has done this business for four years.  She is requesting a loan to buy more sorghum in order to have enough for the demand of her clientele.

loans.use: Buying sorghum

loans.name: Production Plus Group

texts.en:
Production Plus is a community bank made up of 18 members whose chairwoman is Marceline. These members are united for the same goal: to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through the MFI HOPE RDC. 

Marceline sells corn and manioc flour and charcoal. She began her business in 1990 with the starting capital of $20 selling loaves of bread and charcoal. After hard work and good management, she succeeded in making it thrive thanks to the accumulated profits. Marceline is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having three times obtained and correctly repaid loans. 

She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by buying ten 10kg/sacks of corn and manioc flour and reselling them at a profit in her environment. Marceline is 47 years old, married and the mother of 8 children, whose ages vary between 17 and 25 years old. Four of them attend school. Her business generates a profit of $15 per week. Marceline’s dream is to open a manioc and corn facility and become a provider in her area.

loans.use: purchasing corn and manioc flour for resale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Helene

texts.en:
Helene is 39 years old and a mother of 5 children, aged 6, 10, 11, 12, and 14 years.  All of her children are in school.  She is recently divorced, and is proud that she is still able to afford health insurance for the entire family.

Helene runs a business buying crops from farmers and sells the produce locally. Each day she sells in a different market.She has been conducting this business for over 6 years and has become well known in each market where she works. With the loan, she hopes to increase the amount of crops she can buy and invest the profits into developing her business.  

Helene eventually wants to become a wholesaler and sell to the local retailers in each of the markets. She also plans to start selling to government workers in the area.  She also wants to increase the variety of crops she buys and sells.  If business goes well, she plans to pay off her loan as quickly as possible to be able to qualify for a larger loan.  Eventually she hopes to buy a truck to transport her goods.

loans.use: Buying food crops for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline is 32 years old and has 4 children who are between 16 months and 13 years old.  Her husband is a hairdresser. All their children are in school apart from the youngest who is too young to attend school.  Jacqueline has a shop, a small restaurant and a small milling machine, all of which are at different locations. She is requesting a loan to buy a refrigerator for her restaurant business.  This will prevent much of her food from spoiling and enable her to have more food to sell.

loans.use: Buying a refrigerator for her restaurant.

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en: Angelique is 32 years old.  She has 5 children who range from the age of 1-9 years. All her children are in school apart from the two youngest who are not yet of school age.  Her husband is a motorcyclist and farmer. Angelique sells locally-made banana juice and helps her husband with farming.  She has done this business for 3 years. She is requesting a loan to buy a new motorcycle that will be used to transport the items she sells and to transport other goods and people in the area.

loans.use: Buying a motocycle

loans.name: Marceline

texts.en:
Marceline is 29 years old.  She is a mother of four children who are 3, 5, 8 and 9 years old.  Three of her children are in school while the youngest is not yet in school.  Her husband buys and sells goods. 

Marceline owns a bar and she has been in this business for 5 years.  She needs a loan to buy more bottles of alcohol to stock her bar. With the profits, she looks forward to renovating her house, paying her children’s school fees, and saving some money.

loans.use: Buying more alcohol for sale

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 50-year-old widow and has ten children.  The youngest child is 6 years while the eldest is 28 years old.  One of her children is in secondary school.  Two children have completed secondary school but were unable to continue with their studies because she could not afford their school fees.  The other children are in primary school.

Betty has a shop in which she sells various items such as shoes, soap, cooking oil, juices, and Vaseline.  She has been in this business for 10 years. She needs a loan to expand her business by buying products to sell in her store.

loans.use: Buying products in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Cheikh Ibra Fall Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité CHEIKH IBRA FALL est créé le 05 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 13 femmes d'un même quartier. Elles se sont organisées par voisinage et par affinité. 

Madame KHADY M., debout à l'extrême droite sur la photo, vêtue de grand boubou blanc parsemé de points noirs est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 43 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle a adopté une orpheline de 04 ans. 

Elle est vendeuse de tissus et de chaussures. Elle s'approvisionne en Gambie et en Mauritanie. Elle mène cette activité depuis 1996.

Avec son crédit elle va acheter des tissus en basin et Khartoum des écharpes et des chaussures. 

Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et participer à la prise en charge financière de la famille.
texts.en:
The Cheikh Ibra Fall solidarity group was created on 5th December 2007. It is made up of 13 women from the same neighborhood, who are neighbors and/or friends. Mrs. Khady M., who is on the extreme right of the photo and dressed in a large white "boubou" (African dress) sprinkled with black dots, is in charge of the group. She is 43 years old, married and mother to five children. She has also adopted a four-year old orphan. She sells fabrics and shoes. She gets her supplies in Gambia and Mauritania. She has been carrying out this business since 1996. With her new loan she is going to buy damask and "khartoum" fabrics, scarves and shoes. Her aim is to increase her savings and contribute to the costs of looking after her family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase shoes and fabrics

loans.name: Andre

texts.en: Andre is 48 years old and has seven children who are between 10-20 years old. All of them are in school.  He has also adopted three children and he says that paying school fees for all of the children is quite a big challenge. Andrew grows tomatoes and also breaks and sells rocks for construction.  His wife practices agriculture.  Andre is asking for a loan to pay his employees who sell his rocks. With the profits he wants to continue to pay his children’s school fees.

loans.use: Paying his employees

loans.name: Namanve Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Casting her mind back, 32-year-old N. Mariam says her business start-up story is no far cry from the status quo where everyone intending to join any business is given a confidential talk by a close friend. What she has given much thought to during the 7 years of operating a beauty salon business is how she can best enforce and make use of blue print measures aimed at improving the future of her business.  

To that effect, Mariam has constantly been planning on how best she can utilize  her finances. Many "make my business better" thoughts cross her mind, day in, day out, as she well knows how some businesses have unraveled as a result of bad decision-making. With the 160,000 shillings she makes in a week, she knows better apportioning of this money in terms of expenditure is vital, even if she only has one child.  Prior to starting her current main business she was inclined to a hotel and restaurant business. With this loan, she wants to buy more cosmetics for her salon.

loans.use: The purchase of more cosmetics for her beauty salon

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is widowed with six children; none of her children goes to school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).  She owns a stall at her home in Naguru selling charcoal and bananas.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal and to pay school fees for her grandchildren.   

Norah buys bags of charcoal from villages of Luwero District and uses public transport to and from shopping.  Besides this stall business she also gets additional income from rental rooms. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale and works six days a week. Her business challenges include transporting of bags of charcoal from Luwero district to her stall.   

Norah is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and hopes to start selling wholesale only and also to educate her grandchildren up to university.  She decided to work with MCDT because they were cooperative. 

Norah resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food, school fees and paying electricity bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
Dora L. P. tiene 55 años y vive en el barrio Los Almendros de Soledad, es una mujer casada y con tres hijos en las edades de 10 a 32 años, allí en su casa tiene un negocio donde prepara y vende comidas rápidas, como perros calientes, sánduches, chuzos, fritos, que elabora con los más deliciosos aderezos y salsas. 

Hace 10 años inició su actividad con una tienda en otro barrio del municipio de soledad; ella hizo su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para fortalecer este negocio y prosperó con 3 financiamientos mas, pero en su cuarto crédito entristecida  por la pérdida de su hijo al enfermar, terminó con su negocio y  se mudó de su casa y cinco años mas tarde, inició el negocio de venta de fritos y posteriormente cuando una vecina  le enseñó   técnicas de preparación de comidas rápidas para la venta, inició su actual negocio  en reemplazo de su antigua tienda. 

Con la venta de comidas rápidas gradualmente su negocio ha ido creciendo y Dora ha aprovechando muy bien su punto de ventas, primero  alquiló un carro de perros calientes por  sesenta mil pesos mensuales,  y  en el desarrollo de todas estas actividades compró   su carro de perros calientes por un valor de un millón doscientos mil pesos Colombianos y   gradualmente ha ido agregando otros equipos que han ampliado su infraestructura,  primero un calentador, luego sillas y finalmente el horno microondas. 

Actualmente  quiere ampliar la gama de productos que ofrece y adicionar otros  como los de heladería,  venta de masa de maíz, chichas y por eso solicita su credikiva; con el realizará  su primer pedido de helados y comprará al por mayor y de contado las salsas, aderezos  y la harina indispensable en la preparación de sus productos; no obstante, su meta es continuar prosperando su negocio, mediante la diversificación de productos y adicionarle además de heladería, productos de la canasta familiar para emular la prospera tienda que antes tenía.
texts.en:
Dora is 55 years old and lives in the community of Los Almendros de Soledad. She is married and has three children between the ages of 10 and 32. She runs a business out of her home preparing and selling fast food, such as hot dogs, sandwiches, kebabs and french fries, that she makes with the most delicious seasonings and sauces. She started a business 10 years ago with a shop in another neighborhood in Soledad. She used her first loan from Kiva partner Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to strengthen her business and further prospered with three more loans, but during her fourth loan she lost her son to an illness and she closed the business and moved to her home. Five years later, she started her business selling french fries and later when a neighbor showed her the techniques to prepare other fast foods she started her current business in place of the old one. Selling the different kinds of fast foods, her business gradually grew and Dora took advantage of her sales points very well. First, she rented a hot dog cart for 60,000 pesos a month, and later on she purchased a cart for 1.2 million Colombian pesos. She gradually kept adding other equipment to expand her infrastructure, first a heater, then chairs and finally a microwave oven. Currently she wants to expand the range of products she offers and add others like ice cream, pastries and beverages, and that is why she is turning to Kiva. She plans to make her first order of ice cream and purchase the sauces, seasonings and flour necessary to make her products. Her goal is to keep her business prospering by diversifying her products and adding other familiar staples so she can emulate the success of the shop she once had.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Make her first order of ice cream and purchase the sauces, seasonings and flour necessary to make her products

loans.name: Sope Mame Diarra Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de Solidarité SOPE MAME DIARRA est créé le 04 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 11 femmes issues d'un même quartier. Elles ont monté leur groupe par affinité et par voisinage. 

Madame DEMBA DAME S. debout à l'extrême gauche de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 50 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. 

Elle est vendeuse d'encens et de parfums. C'est elle même qui fabrique ses encens et fait ses cocktails de parfums. Elle pratique cette activité depuis environs 07 ans.

Avec son nouveau crédit elle va acheter des produits pour la fabrique de ses encens et de ses parfums

Son objectif est d'aider son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille et renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
The Sope Mame Diarra solidarity group was created on 4th December 2007. It is made up of 11 women from the same neighborhood, who are neighbors and/or friends. Mrs. Demba Dame S., who is on the extreme left of the photo, is in charge of the group. She is 50 years old, married and mother to six children. She sells incense and perfumes. She makes the incense and perfume cocktails herself and has been doing this for seven years. Her new loan will allow her to buy products in order to make up her incense and perfumes. Her aim is to help her husband take care of the family and boost her savings.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase incense and perfumes

loans.name: Modesta

texts.es:
Modesta reside en cantón san Felipe Corinto departamento de Morazán, tiene 40 años de edad vive con sus padres  los cuales dependen de los ingresos que ella obtienen del negocio.
Se dedica desde hace 8 años al negocio lo aprendió gracias a su mama, ella elabora quesadillas artesanales,  pupusas y los vende a los alrededores de la zona donde ella reside y con los vecinos, 
El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de harina azúcar leche y queso para quesadilla y pupusas y otra parte lo invertirá comprando unos cerditos para crecerlos y engordarlos para luego venderlos en el tiangue municipal de Corinto.
Esto  le ayudara a mejorar las ganancias  y ampliar más su negocio ya que la situación económica del país esta crítica y de esta forma salir adelante y poder ayudarle a sus padres.
Sus aspiraciones es tener un negocio más amplio mejores ingresos mejorando así las condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Modesta lives in San Felipe Corinto in the Morazán region. She is 40 years old and lives with her parents, who she supports with income from her business. For the last 8 years she has made quesadillas and “pupusas” (corn tortillas stuffed with meat and cheese), a skill which she learned from her mother. She sells them to her neighbors and to others in the area where she lives. She will invest this loan in the purchase of flour, sugar, milk, and cheese. She will also purchase pigs to raise and sell in the Corinto municipal market. This will help her improve her earnings and develop her business at a time when the economic situation in her country is critical. In this way she will be able to get ahead and be able to help her parents. Her dream is to have a well-developed business, more income, and better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, and cheese

loans.name: Ann Mary

texts.en:
Ann Mary is married to a retired doctor with whom she has four children. None of her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  Ann Mary changed her business enterprise from a retail shop to charcoal selling.  She has been in this business for a few months.  She buys bags of charcoal from villages of Nakasongola District in central northern Uganda. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. 

Besides this charcoal business she owns rental rooms. She sells to all categories of people but wholesale only.  Her business challenges include transportation of bags of charcoal from Nakasongola to her home and defaulters.  She is aspiring of owning a delivery van. Ann Mary joined MCDT because of low interest charged.  She resides in and owns a four-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Aichatou

texts.en: Mrs. Aichatou Adboubari sells charcoal in the Agoé region of Lomé, Togo. She is married to a teacher and together they have four children. Madame A. is 38 years old and has been engaged in selling charcoal for about the last 6 years. This is a lucrative business in Togo as most families use charcoal to heat their cooking stoves. Despite having worked at this business for a long time, this will be Madame A.’s first time taking a loan from WAGES to fund her business. She has requested 300,000 CFA in order to purchase more stocks of charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal

loans.name: Lévitique Plus Group

texts.en:
"Lévitique Plus" is a Community Bank made up of 18 members whose chairwoman is Lukongo M.. These members are united in the goal of growing their businesses by loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC.

Lukongo, a 46-year-old widowed mother of six children between the ages of 11 and 17, three of whom go to school. started her business of selling women’s clothing with $100. Happy to be part of one of Hope’s groups, she has already received two loans that she paid back promptly, and her business has been reinforced through the loans she received. Her business, located in the eastern area of Kinshasa, generates a profit of $40 per week, and she is planning with this next loan to purchase more women’s clothing to resell in order to increase her profit. Lukongo's dream is open a women’s clothing shop.

loans.use: To purchase women’s clothing to resell in order to increase profits

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Halou

texts.en: Mrs. Halou P. sells charcoal out of her home, located in the Agoe neighborhood of Lomé, Togo. She has requested her first loan from WAGES in the amount of 400,000 CFA. Mrs. P. is 34 years old and a widow. She has three children. Since 2003 she has been selling and distributing charcoal from her home. With her 400,000 CFA loan, Madame P. plans to purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Koudavi

texts.en: Mrs. Koudavi A. has a general store in Lomé, Togo. She sells different sorts of groceries like canned goods, fresh vegetables, rice, and other items. She is 33 years old and has 2 children. Her husband is a pastor. Mrs. A. has requested a loan of 200,000 CFA in order to purchase more merchandise to sell in her store. Normally, she purchases her goods from the Grand Marché in Lomé.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Manuel trabaja como abogado en la prefectura de La Paz, tiene dos hijos  de 10 y 6 años de edad respectivamente y su esposa. La familia vive en anticrético en la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito que solicita es para cubrir el costo de un diplomado en Derecho Penal; deesta forma Manuel estará mejor preparado profesionalmente.

Es el Cuarto crédito con IMPRO y el primero que va a través de  Kiva.
texts.en:
Manuel works as a lawyer in La Paz prefecture. He is married and has two children, ages 10 and 6. This family lives under an “anticredito” arrangement (a type of rental agreement where the rent is paid in advance rather than monthly) in the City of El Alto. He will use the money from this loan to cover the cost of a course in criminal rights. This will help Manuel be better prepared professionally. This will be his fourth loan through IMPRO and the first through Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Professional education

loans.name: Ambali

texts.en: Monsieur Ambali O. is 35 years old and lives in his hometown of Lomé, Togo. He works as a tailor at a workshop he calls Ouro Couture, after his last name. He has had this business since 2005. Monsieur Ouro-Akorkio is 35 years old and married to an entrepreneur. They have one child. He has requested a loan of 300,000 CFA in order to purchase an embroidery machine. The addition of this machine to his business will allow Ambali to diversify his offerings and add creativity and style to his services, thus better satisfying his customers and hopefully increasing his profits.

loans.use: To purchase an embroidery machine

loans.name: Yadira Isabel

texts.es:
Yadira García es una mujer dedicada a la marroquinería, oficio que aprendió cuando al trabajar su esposo en un taller que continuamente cerraban, ella fabricaba en su casa y sus productos los distribuía su esposo en  centros comerciales  importantes del centro de Barranquilla y también vendía  al detal en la calle, es decir la producción a cargo de Yadira y la comercialización en manos de su esposo. Toda esta experiencia generó el que   en la actualidad se dedica  exclusivamente a fabricar hermosos y coloridos bolsos, carteras, accesorios sintéticos y muy  modernos, porque Yadira es una mujer comprometida con su trabajo y siempre está atenta a la moda, para crear o emular los mejores diseños que agraden a sus clientes y que sean rentables. 
Este es su segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el primero aumentó su producción convirtiéndolo en un capital de trabajo nuevo, con el que ella no contaba; por eso ahora está solicitando su credikiva  para comprar materias primas e insumos,  como cuerina, pegador, correderas, slider, trabillas, mosquetones goma solución blanca ojetes y cartón, para sacar una nueva colección, aprovechando que se acerca el día del amor y  la amistad y preparándose desde ahora,  para los últimos meses del año, época en la cual  hay una gran demanda de sus productos y  por consiguiente sus ventas se incrementan. 
Su meta es prosperar siempre en su negocio, mediante la expansión y sobre todo el posicionamiento gradual en el mercado, para que su familia progrese.
texts.en:
Yadira García makes leather goods, a trade she learned when her husband worked in a shop that was constantly closing down. She used to work from her home and her husband distributed the products to the major shopping centers in Barranquilla. They also sold retail outside; that is Yadira would manufacture the goods and her husband would sell them. This experience lead to what she does exclusively today, making beautiful and colorful purses, wallets, and very modern synthetic accessories. Yadira is very dedicated to her work and in touch with the current fashion, so that she can create or copy the designs that her customers like best and are most profitable. This will be her second loan through “Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.” The first loan allowed her to increase her production and subsequently created a need for working capital that she had not counted on. Now she is asking for a Kiva loan to buy supplies, such as leather, glue, slide fasteners, straps, carabineers, white glue, eyelets, and cardboard. She want to create a new collection so that she can take advantage of the approaching day of “Love and Friendship,” and also to prepare for the holiday season, when demand for her products goes up and her sales increase. Her goal is to prosper in her business, through expansion, and above all position herself in the market so that her family can get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Abaya

texts.en: Madame Abaya G. sells mobile phone use credits for some of the major cell-phone companies here in Togo. She has been in this business since 2004. As an experienced entrepreneur, this is Madame Gnadouwa's second loan from WAGES. She is requesting 300,000 CFA to help her purchase more phone cards. Her profits will help her care for her two children, along with the income of her husband who is an agricultural engineer.

loans.use: To purchase phone credit recharge cards

loans.name: Maravillas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama MARAVILLAS,  porque a las  clientas son muy devotas de la imagen religiosa del señor de las Maravillas,  que se venera cerca de su comunidad; además de presumirse que hacen maravillas con su dinero,  pues hacen que rinda frutos al 100 % en sus respectivos negocios. Este grupo se encuentra ubicado en Puebla, en México, el grupo está conformado por 10 mujeres exitosas que cuentan con negocios propios y fructíferos, además que es el ciclo cuarto trabajando con credicomun y siempre han sido muy puntuales con sus pagos.  Este préstamo será destinado para comprar materia prima (rollo de peluche, ojos de diferentes tamaños, hilo, relleno)
La Tesorera del grupo se llama María de Lourdes Nieves A. L., es la persona más responsable y honesta  del grupo, motivo por el cual fue elegida para ese puesto dentro de la mesa directiva. Tiene 45 años de edad, estudio hasta la secundaria, es soltera;  se dedica a la elaboración y venta de Artículos de Peluche, es una persona emprendedora, pues ella es la creadora de sus propios diseños;  para sus demás compañeras es un ejemplo a seguir pues con sus mínimo grado de estudios, actualmente y mediante mucho esfuerzo ya cuenta con una vasta cartera de clientes. Para ella el éxito se vería reflejado mediante la creación de su propia fábrica de peluches y su marca registrada, además de soñar sean reconocidos sus diseños a nivel mundial, mediante la exportación de sus productos.   Su meta en la vida es poder ser creadora de F. de empleo para otras mujeres,  que como ella sueñan  con darles a sus familias  una buena educación,  para que no sufran de las carencias que ellas han  pasado, además  de impulsarse como micro empresarias con la ayuda de nuestros créditos.
Las otras integrantes del grupo son:
GABRIELA A. L.           - VENTA DE COSMATICOS,
JOSEFDINA G. T.          – MISCELANEA,
IRMA A. L.               - VENTA DE ZAPATOS
MARIA ROSA IGNACIA G. M. - VENTA DE BLANCOS
OLIVIA CLARA A. L.       – VENTA DE JUGOS
MARIA DEL CARMEN A. G.   – LAVANDERIA
MARIA SOLEDAD C. C.      – VENTA DE ROPA
CECILIA F. G.            – COMIDA
SUSANA C. F.             – VENTA DE TRASTES.
texts.en:
This group is called “MARAVILLAS” (Marvelous) because its members are very devoted to the religious image of the Marvelous Lord, which is venerated near their community. They are also proud because they do marvelous things with their money, making it return 100% profit in their respective businesses. This group is located in Puebla, Mexico and is made up of ten achieving women, each having her own successful business. This is their fourth cycle working with CreditComun and they have always been punctual with their payments. They will use the money from this loan to buy supplies (fabric for making stuffed animals, different sizes of artificial eyes, thread, and stuffing). The group’s treasurer is named María de Lourdes Nieves A.L. and she is the group’s most honest and responsible person. This is why she was elected to this position among the other officers. She is 45 years old, has a junior high school education, is single, and makes and sells stuffed animals. She is a very enterprising woman and designs her own items. Her peers see her as a person to be emulated, despite her limited formal education. With a lot of effort she’s been able to establish a large number of customers. For her, success would mean opening her own stuffed animal factory and creating her own brand. She also dreams of becoming known throughout the world and exporting her products. Her goal in life is to create jobs for other women, who, like her, dream of providing good educations for their families, so that they don’t suffer from the same needs that they have had to deal with. These loans have made it possible for each of them establish their small businesses. The other members of the group are: Gabriela A. L. – Cosmetic sales Josefdina G. T. – General merchandise Irma A. L. – Shoe sales Maria Rosa Ignacia G. M. – White sales Olivia Clara A. L. – Juice sales Maria Del Carmen A. G. – Washing Maria Soledad C. C. – Clothing sales Cecilia F. G. – Food sales Susana C. F. – Dish sales

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Dermane

texts.en: Dermane H. sells shoes. He has been working in Lome, Togo as a shoe seller since 2003. Normally, he gets his merchandise from the Grand Market in Lome. This time around, Monsieur H. has decided to take a loan of 300,000 CFA to help him purchase his stock and increase his commercial activity. He will invest in new products to satisfy his customers. Monsieur H. is married to another vendor and they have two children.

loans.use: To purchase shoes

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr:
Madame Aïssatou D. est âgée de 45 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du banc Villageois de WALIDANE novembre 2004. Elle a 1 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit auprès de CAURIE-MICROFONANCE.

Elle fait de l'embouche bovine. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 5 ans. 

Avec son nouveau prêt elle va acheter 6 bœufs et de l'aliment pour bétail. Elle engraissera les animaux pendant au moins 5 mois avant de les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. 

Son objectif est de participer financièrement à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et augmenter le niveau de son épargne.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aïssatou D. is 42 years old, married and the mother of 6 dependent children. She has been a member of the WALIDANE Banc Villageois since November 2004. She has had 1 loan from CAURIE-MICROFINANCE. She raises cattle and has operated this business for more than 5 years. She is going to buy six steers and livestock feed with her new loan. She is going to fatten the animals for at least 5 months before selling them in the weekly markets in her area. Her goal is to contribute financially to the improvement of her family’s living conditions and to increase the level of her savings.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy three pair of steers

loans.name: Yanina

texts.es: Yanina, de 26 años, vive en su casa propia en compañía de su esposo Oswaldo de 30 años, que es chofer, y de sus 2 hijas pequeñas. Recuerda como desde muy pequeña veía a sus familiares trabajar la tierra, y aunque confiesa que le gusta un poco esa labor, cuando ya era joven empezó a inclinarse por el rubro comercial. En la actualidad se dedica al comercio de ropa que trae desde la ciudad hasta su pueblo natal, ya tiene clientes fijos y algunos recomendados, pero concede las prendas a crédito solo a personas de confianza. Le va bien en el negocio porque obtiene regulares ganancias que le permiten ayudar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar. Como es una mujer que piensa en grande para mas adelante tiene planeado comercializar todo tipo de ropa, tanto para damas y caballeros, pero al por mayor ya que le parece tedioso viajar constantemente al interior del país. Es el primer crédito con MFP, y promete pagar sus cuotas puntualmente para continuar progresando, además esta satisfecha con la organización de su grupo comunal ya que esta integrado por personas bastante responsables. Yanina tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de mayor cantidad de mercadería, pues quiere ofrecer a sus clientes variedad, y así espera mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Yanina is 26 years old and lives in her own home, along with her 30 year old husband, Oswaldo (who works as a driver) and with her two young daughters. She recalls watching her family work the land when she was very young, and admits to liking that work a bit, but she began leaning toward more commercial entries when she was still young. She currently sells clothing that she brings to her village from the city. She has some regular customers and some recommended to her, but she only grants credit to those she trusts. Her business is doing well and she brings in a regular income, allowing her to help her husband pay the household expenses. Because she thinks big about the future, she plans to sell all sorts of clothing for women and men, but finds it tedious to constantly have to travel to the center of the country.
