loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia pertenece al Banco Comunal Azucenas y lo que mas le agrada es el incentivo al ahorro.
Julia es casada y tiene 10 hijos, actualmente vive solo con su esposo, Julia vive en la comunidad D. San Juan D. la Frontera en donD. tiene tierras que cultiva produciendo flores, además se dedica a la crianza D. cuy para lo cual siembra alfalfa para la alimentación, sus ventas lo realiza en el mismo lugar.
Julia solicita un crédito D. 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. alimento balanceado.
texts.en:
Julia belongs to Communal Bank White Lilies and what appeals to her the most is the incentive of saving. Julia is married and has 10 children but as of now lives only with her husband. Julia lives in San Juan D. la Frontera where she has land that she cultivates to produce flowers. She also raises guinea pigs for which she grows alfalfa to feed. She makes her sales in the same location. Julia is requesting a 1500 Peruvian Soles loan to purchase a balanced animal feed.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of a balanced feed.

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
Esther es casada y tiene 10 hijos D. los cuales 3 estudian, Esther viaja a las ferias D. la región en donD. venD. verduras, frutas y condimentos, D. las ferias compra queso que luego venD. en los mercados y las tiendas, actividad que realiza 3 días por semana. 

Esther es socia del Banco Comunal Azucenas y solicita un préstamo D. 1000 soles para la compra D. verduras y frutas.

Los sueños D. Esther son educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales y ampliar su negocio surtiendo con mas productos.
texts.en:
Esther is married and has 10 children, 3 of which are students. Esther travels to regional fairs and sells vegetables, fruits, and condiments. She buys cheese at the fair and then sells it to markets and stores three days a week. Esther is a member of Lilies Communal Bank and is requesting a 1000 Peruvian Soles loan to buy vegetables and fruits. Esther's dreams are to educate her children so they can become professionals and expand her business by offering more products.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Fiapule

texts.en: Fiapule T. is 34 and married with three children. She plants and harvests taro for sale. Fiapule has five years of experience in this business. Fiapule needs a loan of 2,500 Samoan talas to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or $146 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family. In 2007, Fiapule joined SPBD. This is her fourth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Fiapule's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD. http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Luz María

texts.es:
Luz es una madre D. familia D. 50 años D. edad que vive junto a su esposo en el caserío Pueblo Nuevo Tejedores del distrito agrícola D. TambogranD., la zona se caracteriza por producir principalmente frutas para exportación, el distrito pertenece a la provincia D. Piura y se encuentra ubicada en la región del mismo nombre, a mas D. tres horas D. la ciudad D. Chiclayo, capital D. la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a la venta D. golosinas y D. diversos artículos en una bodega instalada en su domicilio, ella se vale D. este negocio para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos familiares, además la hace sentirse activa y util, sus principales clientes son los niños y jóvenes D. la zona, ella trata D. brindarles productos D. buena calidad para poder mantener su negocio, durante el tiempo que lleva en el negocio se ha hecho conocida por la zona.

Luz desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo mas productos, para lograr su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a realizar su objetivo.

Luz es una mujer trabajadora, emprendedora y entregada a su hogar. Su mayor anhelo es seguir trabajando para mejorar gradualmente la calidad D. vida D. su familia.
texts.en:
Luz is a mother, is 50 years old, and lives with her husband in the farmhouse Pueblo Nuevo Tejedores of the TambogranD. district. The area is mainly characterized by producing fruits for exporting. The district belongs to the Piura province and is located on the region of the same name which is more than three hours from the city of Chiclayo, capital of the Lambayeque region.

She sells sweets and various items in a shop installed in her home. She cares about this business to help her husband with family expenditures. In addition it makes her feel active and useful. Her main clients are children and young women and men from the area. She tries to keep their business by offering them high quality products . During the time she has been running her business she is well known in the area.

Luz wants to expand her business by adding more products. To achieve her goal she found it convenient to request her first loan to Edpyme Alternativa; she request a 500 Peruvian Soles loan to carry out her goal.

Luz is a hardworking woman, aspiring, and devoted to her home. Her biggest wish is to continue working to gradually improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of more sweets to increase her sales.

loans.name: Shayamie

texts.en:
Shayamie A. is from the village of D'ban Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Shayamie is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Shayamie owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food and drinks for the local community. Shayamie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 85,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Shayamie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shayamie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Shayamie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Zenobia

texts.es:
Zenobia es profesora de profesión, es casada, tiene 38 años y 1 hijo, Zenobia tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, frutas, actividad que realiza todos los días desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche. 
Zenobia es socia del Banco Comunal Azucenas y solicita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que sera invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar y cerveza.
Los sueños de Zenobia son ampliar su bodega, construir un ambiente mas grande para su tienda.
texts.en:
Zenobia, 38, is married and has one son; she’s a teacher by profession. She has a grocery store in her home where she stocks assorted groceries, vegetables and fruit. She is open for business every day from 6am until 9pm. Zenobia is a member of the Azucenas (Easter Lilies) communal bank and is asking for a 1250 sol loan to buy rice, sugar and beer. Zenobia’s dream is to expand her stock and build a larger space for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar and beer.

loans.name: Merlyn's Group

texts.en:
Merlyn G. is from the village of Tipolo Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Merlyn is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Tropicana 2.

Merlyn is widowed and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits like "marang", banana and more in the local community. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Merlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Merlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Valasiolagi

texts.en: Valasiolagi B. is 42 and married with two children. She owns a business venture to sell a variety of different products in the local community. Valasiolagi has two years of experience in this business. Valasiolagi needs a loan of 2,500 Somoan talas to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or $208 per week) to improve/expand the business. In 2009, Valasiolagi joined SPBD. This is her second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Valasiolagi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. loans.name: Florajaida

texts.en:
Florajaida R. is from the city of Labo Ozamiz City. She is 68 years old. Florajaida is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, Florajaida owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products like candies, toothpaste, soap and the like in the local community. Florajaida has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 20000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Florajaida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and the ability to engage in business activities. Florajaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. Florajaida is requesting a new loan which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Florajaida from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en:
Clementina S. is from the village of Panduma, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 45 years-old and married with six school-aged children. To make a living, Clementina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from buying and selling dried fish and vegetables in the local community. Clementina has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Clementina joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clementina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Clementina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Clementina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of the her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Leodegario

Leodegario C. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 56 years-old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Leodegario owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from providing a junkshop in the local community. Leodegario has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 13,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Leodegario joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leodegario has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leodegario is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leodegario from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Faleseu

texts.en: Faleseu R. is 46 and married with seven children. She plants and harvests taro for sale. Faleseu has four years of experience in this business. Faleseu needs a loan of 2,500 Samoan tala to purchase harvesting equipment, such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets and knives. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or about $167 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees. In 2007, Faleseu joined SPBD. This is her fifth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Faleseu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria pertenece al Banco Comunal El Roble y durante el tiempo que es socia aprendió a ahorrar.
Maria es casada y tiene 9 hijos todos ahora independiente, Maria ahora tiene a su responsabilidad 2 nietos que estudian y espera que sean profesionales, Maria venD. frutas, chicha, bebidas, en la puerta D. su casa, actividad que realiza todos los días. Solicita un prestamo D. 1000 soles para la compra D. bebidas variadas.
texts.en:
Maria belongs to the El Roble communal bank, and during her time as a member, she has learned to save money. Maria is married and has nine children, all adults now. Maria is now responsible for two grandchildren who study, and she hopes they become professionals. Maria sells fruits, chicha [a traditional beverage], and drinks from the doorway of her house, an activity which she does everyday. She asks for a loan of 1000 soles to buy a variety of drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: variety of drinks

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos que estudian, Gregoria se dedica a la agricultura de verduras en el valle de compañía, además compra verduras de los productores para luego comercializarlo en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad, actividad que inicia a las 2 de la mañana. 
Gregoria pertenece al Banco Comunal El Roble y solicita un crédito de 1500 soles para la compra de semillas y abono.
Gregoria sueña con educar a sus hijos y ahorrar para alguna emergencia en el futuro.
texts.en:
Gregoria has a live-in partner and two children who are students. She is a vegetable farmer in Valle de Compañía. She also buys vegetables from producers that she later sells in the city’s wholesale foodstuffs market, an activity she begins at 2am. Gregoria is a member of the El Roble (The Oak) communal bank and is asking for a 1500 sol loan to buy seed and manure. She dreams with providing an education for her children and to save for any future emergency.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seed and manure.

loans.name: Eline

texts.en:
Eline P. is 26 and married with 3 children.  She owns a business venture planting and harvesting bananas for sale.  Eline has 2 years of experience in this business.  Eline needs a loan of WST$1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.


In 2008, Eline joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.  SPBD's loans are Eline's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Erika

texts.es:
Erika pertenece al Banco Comunal El Roble y durante el tiempo que es socia aprendió a ser puntual y ahorrar.
Erika es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos, Erika tiene cabinas de Internet en su casa, tiene 9 maquinas, ella se encarga de la atención todos los días. Además Erika tiene un carro que realiza transporte publico en la ciudad de Ayacucho, Erika tiene proyectado vender artículos de librería en el mismo local.
Erika solicita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cuadernos, lapiceros, papeles.
Los sueños de Erika son mejorar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Erika is a member of the El Roble (The Oak) communal bank and while being a member has learned how to be punctual and how to save. She has a live-in partner and two children. She has 9 Internet access booths installed in her home; she is open for business every day. In addition, Erika has a car that provides public transportation services in the city of Ayacucho. She intends to sell stationery items in her locale. She is asking for a 2000 sol loan to buy notebooks, mechanical pencils and paper. Erica’s dream is to improve her business and provide a good education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy notebooks, mechanical pencils, paper.

loans.name: Talalelei

texts.en: Talalelei L. is 50 and married with six children whose ages range from 13 to 35. She is starting a business venture to sell pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam). Talalelei needs a loan of 2,200 Samoan talas to buy flour, flavoring, sugar and plastic bags. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or about $167 per week) to improve/expand the business. In 2008, Talalelei joined SPBD. This is her fourth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Talalelei's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD. http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma es casada y tiene 2 hijos que estudian, Vilma viaja a la selva ayacuchana a donde lleva abarrotes en general, para lo cual tiene un carro que es conducido por su esposo, vende en diferentes pueblos y de la selva ayacuchana compra frutas que luego son vendidas en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad.
Vilma es socia del Banco Comunal El Roble y solicita un crédito de 750 soles para la compra de galletas, golosinas.
Los sueños de Vilma son tener capital propio y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Vilma is married and has two children who are students. She travels to the Ayacucho backcountry to sell groceries. She has a car that her husband drives for this. She sells in various towns and brings back fruit from there to sell in the city’s wholesale foodstuffs market. Vilma is a member of the El Roble (The Oak) communal bank and is asking for a 750 sol loan to buy cookies and sweets. Vilma’s dream is to have her own capital and expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cookies and sweets.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa pertenece al Banco Comunal El Roble y lo que mas le agrada es el incentivo al ahorro.
Rosa es casada, tiene 34 años y 3 hijos, Rosa tiene una tienda en un local alquilado en donde vende lubricantes, también brinda el servicio de cambio de aceite, actividad que realiza todos los días con su esposo.
Rosa necesita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de lubricantes.
Los sueños de Rosa son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener local propio y trabajar para tener capital propio.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the El Roble (The Oak) communal bank. What she enjoys the most about it are the savings incentives. Rosa, 34, is married and has three children. She has a rented location where she sells auto lubricants. She also provides vehicle oil change service every day with help from her husband. Rosa needs a 1250 sol loan to buy auto lubricants. Rosa’s dream is that her children become professionals, to own her own locale and to work to have her own capital.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Artesanos Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Artesanos inicia su noveno ciclo con 13 socias que son de la comunidad de Huascahura que se encuentra a 15 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de comida, carne, artesanía.
Como es el caso de la señora Brigida que es casada, tiene 44 años y 1 hijo pequeño, Brigida es muy entusiasta y ahora es presidenta de su Banco Comunal, Brigida tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, menestras, bebidas. Además Brigida junto a su esposo se dedican a la compra y venta de ganado. 
Hace 6 meses Brigida tuvo una intervención quirúrgica la cual supero a pesar del miedo que sentía por su mal y estuvo trabajando normalmente y hace 3 meses sufrió un robo en su tienda, pero a pesar de las adversidades ella continua trabajando para salir adelante.
Su préstamo será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar para surtir su tienda.
Los sueños de Brigida son que sus hijos sean profesionales y vender el ganado en la ciudad de Lima.
texts.en:
The Artisans’ Community Bank is starting its ninth loan cycle with 13 members who are from the community of Huascahura, located about 15 minutes from the town of Ayachucho. The members are involved in different businesses such as selling food, meat, and crafts. One of the members is Sra. Brigida who is 44 years old, married, and has a young son. She is a very enthusiastic person and currently is president of the community bank. She runs a store out of her home selling groceries, vegetables, soups, and soft drinks. Together with her husband, Brigida also buys and sells livestock. Six months ago she had an operation which she recovered from despite being frightened of what her illness meant. She was working normally when three months ago her store was robbed. However, in spite of all these problems she is continuing to work and make progress. Brigida will use her loan to buy rice and sugar to put in her store. Her dreams are to see her children get good jobs and sell livestock in the city of Lima.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Jim

texts.en:
Jim B. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 32 years-old and married with one baby. To make a living, Jim owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Jim has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jim joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jim is requesting a first loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more products to expand the business.. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Kalala

texts.en:
Kalala S. is 43 and married with five children (ages 8 - 20).  She owns a business venture planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Kalala has three years of experience in this business.  Kalala needs a loan of WST $2,000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Kalala joined SPBD. This is her third loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Kalala's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD: 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as to Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD. http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products like soap, noodles, and toothpaste in the local community. Florence has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florence joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florence has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Florence is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Florence from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bolinchuluun

texts.en: Bolinchuluun J. is 51 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Central province of Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her youngest daughter attends secondary school. Bolinchuluun operates a retail vegetable business out of a rented stall at a local market in her town. She began her business in 1999 with working capital of 500,000 MNT. Now it has reached 2,800,000 MNT. She would like to begin a new retail business along with her current one. She works hard to provide for her three children and wants to be able to continue to pay their school fees so they can all get good educations and not have to struggle like she has. Bolinchuluun is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase other types of vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase other types of vegetables

loans.name: Badamgarav

texts.en: Badamgarav H. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Central province of Mongolia, in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son attends a local primary school while her husband has been working as a driver in the power station of the province for eleven years. Badamgarav has run a food retailing business since 2008 out of two rented stalls at the local market called Altan-Eh. She decided to start her business when she worked for a local garment factory and traveled a lot to China and gained experience in how to manage a business. She began with working capital of one million MNT and it has now reached 4,300,000 MNT. Thanks to her successful business, Badamgarav was able to remodel the yard and house in where the family lives. She says: “I would have a comfortable apartment with my business profit.” Badamgarav is a hard-working woman who is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a fridge, freezer, and also increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge, freezer

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en: Oyuntsetseg B. is 47 years old and has been living with her husband and daughter in the central province of Mongolia for 30 years. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her husband works as a driller for the Central Water Company in their town while her daughter is a student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Oyuntsetseg operates a hair salon in her town, sharing the salon and the rent with several of her friends who are beauticians and hairdressers. Oyuntsetseg started the salon in 1980 and since then her business has grown steadily over the years and is popular in the area. Although her cooperation with her friends has proven to be successful, Oyuntsetseg dreams of being on her own. She says, "I would like to open my own beauty and hair salon in the future." She is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan to purchase beauty products for her business and to use some of the money for her daughter's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en:
Faafetai L. is 50 and married with eight children whose ages range from 5 to 20. She plants and harvests taro for sale. Faafetai has many year of experience in this business. Faafetai needs a loan of 1,000 Samoan talas to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or about $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Faafetai joined SPBD. This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Faafetai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

SPBD's loans are Orepa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD. http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad lives in the small city of Borewala in Punjab, Pakistan in a two room brick house with her husband, daughter and five sons. Her husband is involved in a bike rental business, aided by their eldest son. Irshad does embroidery work part-time to contribute financially to her family. 

Irshad has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband to improve the condition of his business. With the loan amount, he will buy another motorbike to rent to expand his business. He has been running this business for the last 20 years and Irshad believes that her husband can increase his income with the help of a loan investment. She is in her fourth loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah. In her past loan experiences, she maintained a good credit record and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: to purchase another motorbike for a bike rental business

loans.name: Parveen Kousar's Group

texts.en:

He repairs motorbikes and also offers motor bike spare parts for sale in his shop. Parveen is a seamstress and embroiders clothes for her clients. She is well known among her clients for her quality works and gets regular orders. 

Parveen has given birth to 2 daughters and a son. Her daughters are in 3rd and 5th grades while her son is in 3rd grade. She wants to give quality education to her children and that is why she works very hard.

Parveen kousar lives in a small house with 3 bed rooms and has minimized her expenses to afford the school fee of her children. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband financially. With the loan he will buy spare parts for motorbike repair.  Parveen believes that by using his 10 years of experience in this profession, her husband will be able to get full benefits with this investment.  She is in her 4th loan cycle. In the past years loan experience she has maintained a good credit record and never missed a loan group meeting.

loans.name: Kousar

texts.en:
Kousar lives in a two room brick house in a small city called Borewala, which is located in Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 20 years with her family. Kousar has two sons and a daughter. All are illiterate and could not get an education due to financial problems.

She is a housewife and stays at home to take care of her family. She manages the household chores. She also works part-time as an embroiderer for her neighborhood clients so she can contribute financially to her family.

Her husband is a painter. He paints walls, doors and windows to earn money. He has been doing this business for the past 10 years.

Kousar has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. He will use the loan to buy paint of different colors so he can improve his business.

She is hopeful that her husband will be able to increase his income and improve the living standard of the family.

loans.use: To purchase paint boxes for painting business

loans.name: Rowena Ann

texts.en:
Rowena Ann R. is from the village of Brgy, Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 33 years old. Rowena Ann is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena Ann owns and operates a business venture in the transportation sector. The main source of income for the business is from operating a motorcycle for transport. Rowena Ann has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rowena Ann joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rowena Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Rowena Ann is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her existing vehicle so it can operate more efficiently. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rowena Ann from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her existing vehicle

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna O. is from the village of Macate Diffun. She is 40 years old. Lorna is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a business venture in the arts sector; she operates a handicraft business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling handicraft bags. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lorna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials in order to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios L. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal West, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 52 years old. Remedios is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Remedios owns and operates a tailoring business. The main source of income comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and threads. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Remedios from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and threads

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia P. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 44 years old. Lilia is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing sound system services to local community members. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Lilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Lilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Enhee

texts.en: Enhee I. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Baganuur, an outlying district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of her children attend a local middle school while her husband helps her out with her business. Enhee and her husband started a transportation business in 2004. Enhee is committed to not only improving the lives of her husband and children, but she and her husband also want to expand their business by opening their own taxi-service center. Enhee is a hard working and gentle woman who says, “We want to provide our customers with fast, safe and reliable service ”.  She is requesting a 500,000MNT loan to buy new accumulator and motor for her car.

loans.use: To buy new accumulator and motor for her car

loans.name: Najma Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Najma perveen lives in a small city called Borewala, which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She is 36 years old and has spent most of her life in Borewala. She owns a small house of only two rooms and lives in it with her family. She is a housewife and stays at home to do her household responsibilities. Her husband's name is M. S.. He is involved in the business of selling fertilizer & seeds. He has been doing this work for over 10 years. 

Najma helps her family financially by doing sewing work. She gets orders from her relatives and neighbors and charges from them 100-130 PKRs for each dress. Her earning allows her to pay for the utilities and to manage the kitchen in her home. She has given birth to three sons and a daughter who are all illiterate because they couldn’t provide them with a better education. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will buy fertilizer and seeds in bulk and meet the orders of his customers. 
Najma hopes that by investing money in her husband’s business, he will be able to make more money, which will help Najma’s family to enjoy a better financial life.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer & seeds to sell

loans.name: Gotov

texts.en:
Gotov C. is 52 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Govi-Altay province in western Mongolia. His son attends a local high school while his wife helps him out with the business. The family's living conditions are good and this is possible because of his consumer goods trading business at a local market. 

Gotov sells a variety of clothes and garments to customers. He purchases most of their goods from Beijing, China, once or twice a month depending on sales and transports them back to the market to sell. Gotov started his business in 2002 with the working capital of 1,200,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) and has quickly established himself in the local business community. 

In 2004, he received a 600,000 MNT loan from Xacbank and paid the loan off in full, on time. Now his working capital exceeds 8,000,000 MNT. Gotov and his family hope to soon expand their business and increase their earnings. 

Gotov is a gentle, hardworking and neat man. He says, “I am trying my best to save money for my son's education and enlarge my business in the future. I wish I would have a small clothes store in my town.” 

He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes and warm garments to sell for the upcoming autumn season.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran lives in a city called Borewala, which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She is 33-year-old lady who makes hand-made fans to support her family. She is very good at her art and she makes a good income from her quality work. Hand-made work always gets preference in every field. She has this talent as a gift from God. 

She started doing this work independently after her marriage to contribute financially to her family. She supplies the fans to different cities but in Multan specifically because this is the city that is renowned for hand-made items.
  
Her husband runs a cold-drink corner, where he sells different brands of cold drinks such as Coca-Cola, Pepsi and 7-Up. He also supplies those bottles to others cold-drink corners. He has more than 15 years of experience in this field. 

Sughran is the mother of a son and two daughters who couldn’t get an education due to poor financial conditions. 

Sughran has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband financially. With the loan amount, her husband will buy bottles to fulfill larger orders on time. She prays to God that in this way, her husband’s income may increase more. 

She is in her third loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah. In the past two years of loan experience, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

Note: In this photo, all the ladies are holding the hand-made fans made by Sughran, the group leader.

loans.use: Purchase cold drinks to fulfill larger orders

loans.name: Tumennast

texts.en:
Tumennast A. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in the Central province of Mongolia in a ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Her daughter is going to get married soon while her husband is self-employed. 

Tumennast operates a hairdresser's salon in a rented space in her town with some of her friends. They work in shifts: Two of them work before noon, while the other two work during the evening time. She began her business in 1985 and it has grown steadily over the years due to her loyal customers.

Tumennast wants one day to create her own workplace and she would like to work on her own. She has purchased a small car with her business earnings and is now trying to innovate. Tumennast is a hardworking and modest woman who is requesting a 2,400,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase more beauty products and tools for her growing salon.

loans.use: To purchase more beauty products

loans.name: Rukhsana's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana is 36 years of age and lives in a city called Borewala in Pakistan with her three sons and a daughter. None of them could get an education due to financial constraints. Her sons had to start work in their early age to support the family financially. Her eldest son is a painter. He paints on walls, doors and windows and the youngest son does welding.

Rukhsana is a housewife who spends most of her time managing her household chores. Her home is a small one and only consists of two rooms. 
She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her son. With the loan, he will buy different colors and brands of paint to offer quality services to his clients.  
Rukhsana is hopeful that with the help of an increased income, she will be able to marry her daughter who is in her marriage age.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of paint

loans.name: Batbold

texts.en: Batbold T. lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, in a ger- a traditional nomadic housing tent. Since 2004, Batbold has been operating a shoe business in Narantuul Trade market, the biggest and most crowded market in the city. He provides a variety of shoes to satisfy the customer's needs and imports the shoes from China. He owns a stall in the market where he sells the products.  After some years of positive growth with his business, he was able to increase his working capital to 3,000,000 MNT with a daily profit of 80,000 MNT and was able to purchase a plot of land where his family currently lives. Today, the family enjoys a stable operation with the businesses and is focused on expanding their shoe trade business in the near future.  Batbold is a very modest person. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to import a large number of shoes from Beijing, the capital city of China.

loans.use: To import a large number of shoes from Beijing

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok N. is 39 years of age and a married woman. She is a good homemaker who either takes care of her children or arranges a daily routine from home. She has six children, almost all of whom are single and live at home. She relies on the income from three of her daughters who work as sewing laborers in the clothing industry and from her husband who works in the construction sector. 

She is concerned that she doesn’t have a bathroom to take care of the sanitation needs of her family. Therefore, she is seeking a loan to use towards building a bathroom.

loans.use: To use towards building a bathroom.

loans.name: Abida's Group

texts.en:
Abida lives in Borewala, Pakistan, which is a small city located in Punjab province of Pakistan. She moved to her current home with her family seven years ago. 

Her husband runs a motor-workshop. He is a very good car mechanic and has a very good reputation among his customers for his technical abilities. 

Abida is the mother of two sons. None of them could get their education because Abida and her husband couldn’t afford their school fees. One of them works as a driver. 

Abida does embroidery work for neighborhood clients. With her art she crafts beautiful embroidery designs and earns a good income. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially help her husband. With the loan he will buy the latest repairing tools and will hire a mechanic at his workshop to provide quick services to his customers and to expand his business. 

She is in her 4th loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah. This time she is hopeful that with the investment in her husband’s business, his business will produce more income and her family will be able to enjoy a better standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase latest repairing tools for motor-workshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food to sell in his store

loans.name: Zarina's Group

texts.en:
Zarina lives with her family in a city called Borewala which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She has spent twenty years of her life in this city. Her husband is a butcher by profession and sells chicken meat specifically. 

She is the mother of four sons and two daughters. All of them are getting their education and studying in different classes. It is very difficult for Zarina and her husband to afford their children’s education. Her husband is barely able to fulfill the family's basic needs. Therefore, Zarina has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. 

With the loan, he will buy more chickens to fill larger orders, particularly during the wedding season.  Zarina is hopeful that her husband will be able to upgrade his business. He has been in this business for the past fifteen years and has vast experience in this field. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her 3rd loan cycle. She has proven to be a responsible person in her previous two years of loan experience.

loans.use: Purchase chickens for chicken meat selling business

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Epifania S. is from the village of Tambagan, Gingoog City. She is 50 years old, married, and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she  raises pigs to sell. Epifania has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $117 a month for these activities.

In 2002, Epifania joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. 

Epifania is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana is a 37-year-old lady who has been living with her family in a three-room brick house in the city of Borewala in Pakistan for the last ten years. Her husband sells clothes and she is a seamstress. She started this work because her husband needed her financial support in order to fulfill the basic needs of the family which consists of three sons and two daughters. All are getting their education from a local school. 

Rehana is well-known in the surrounding areas for her quality work and this becomes the source of her getting orders regularly. 

Her husband purchases clothes from Multan, which is famous for its embroidery and well-made garments, and sells them to a local market in Borewala. 

Rehana has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. To minimize his cost of travelling and the purchase price as well, he will buy clothes in bulk, according to the latest fashion and trends,

She is hopeful that her husband will be able to improve his business soon and that her family will be able to enjoy a better financial life. She is in her 2nd loan cycle and is a very responsible user of Asasah. She has maintained a good credit record and has never missed any meeting.

loans.use: Purchase clothes in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Jiparkul

texts.en:
Jiparkul  S. was born in the north of Kyrgyzstan.  She is 47 years old, married, and has three children: two sons and one daughter, who is an overachieving student.  Her husband works as an electrician. After graduating from college, Jiparkul worked as an accountant at the local hospital. Her colleagues characterize her as a very diligent and responsible person.  

Unfortunately, salaries in rural areas are very low and Jiparkul decided to produce and sell lepeshka (flat loaves of bread). But it was not a very profitable activity and additional earnings were required in order to support her family.

 A few years ago, using starting capital of only 1,000 KGS, Jiparkul decided to start her business in cattle-breeding and bought sheep.  She concentrated all her efforts on supporting and expanding her household. For this very reason, Jiparkul wants to take out a loan of 120,000 KGS to buy three bull-calves and 20 sheep for fattening and reselling. With the revenue from this investment, Jiparkul plans to give higher education to her children. In future, Jiparkul plans to develop her farm by means of livestock breeding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.  Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase 3 bull-calves and 20 sheep

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda P. is from the village of Mercado Avenue, Gingoog City. She is 60 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests corn to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $210 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. Florenda is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

location.town: Mercado Avenue, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Adelma

texts.en:
Adelma B. is from the village of Consuelo, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 55 years old, a widow, and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $180 a month for these activities.

In 1998, Adelma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Adelma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim lives with her husband and five children in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. She is a very talented lady. She prepares embroidered clothes for her neighbors to earn an income. She is particularly excellent with her hand-made embroidery. With her art she crafts beautiful embroidered designs on clothes and attracts more customers with her work. 

She is the mother of five children, two sons and three daughters. None of them could get an education due to financial constraints. Both of her sons work. The older one sells shawls and the younger one sells clothes by going door to door in communities. 

Her husband runs a clothiing shop in the market. He buys the clothes from cities Multan and Lahore. These days her husband is facing the problem of low inventory and is unable to fulfill the requirements of the customers. Therefore, she has applied for a loan for the 3rd time from Asasah to financially help her husband. 

With the loan he will buy clothes in bulk for selling. This will not only cut the cost of traveling but also he will be able to buy the clothes on discount as a result of bulk purchasing. Shamim is hopeful that this investment will bring happiness to her family and that her family’s standard of living will improve.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Anjeanith

texts.en:
Anjeanith B. is from the village of Duka, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $223 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anjeanith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Anjeanith is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Kolo Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
This enterprisingly dedicated married mother of five school-going children is gleeful in paying tribute to her husband whom she credits with the pep talk that, at length, led her to start up her first business selling snacks.

With the little profits that had accrued from this business, N. Molly began her current food-selling business in Kolo, Mukono. This business has now lasted seven years and makes 200,000 shillings a month.

With this loan, Molly wants to buy materials for the expansion of her restaurant and purchase more food for her canteen. She is a really hardworking and determined lady.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for the expansion of her business and more food for her canteen

loans.name: Jesus Cares Group, Mukono

texts.en:
Anybody in Uganda would be exhilarated at the prospect of running a business venture whose weekly profits add up to 140,000 shillings. With enough resourcefulness and a sense of purpose, a certain 45-year-old married father of five, going by the name of K. Pascoli, has found himself in this enviable position for the last twenty-five years In Kyaliwajjala, Mukono.

Pascoli’s shoemaking and sales business has, in a way, propelled him to some considerable financial glory, notwithstanding the fact that he, in most cases, faces problems of shortage of shoemaking materials. This has often been his biggest undoing. Despite this, he has made sure that his family of his wife and five kids bask in the modest glow of his business.

This was Pascoli’s first business and he started it after apprenticeship training in a shoemaking factory. With this loan, he wants to restock his business. This, in essence, means he wants to purchase more leather shoemaking material. This, he says, will enable him make more shoes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more leather shoemaking material

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en: Liezel P. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 33 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Liezel owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Liezel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Liezel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Ammie

texts.en: Ammie D. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 38 years old and is married with three adult children. Ammie owns and operates a business providing transportation services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,800 PHP a month. In 2008, Ammie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to repair the vehicle used in her business. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair the vehicle used in her business

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is now widowed with four children and two of her children go school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and food.

Ruth owns a stall selling charcoal and foodstuffs and has been in this business for many years. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans which get them from villages, and foodstuffs from Kasubi market. She uses public transport to and from Kasubi. Besides this charcoal business she also sells piped water.

Ruth works from her home and sells retail, working six days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She is aspiring to see her business grow big and to start going directly to farmers and producers.

Ruth decided to work with MCDT because it is helping low-income women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal and bags of cassava, potatoes and tomatoes.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and bags of cassava, potatoes and tomatoes

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Salma lives the small city of south Punjab Pakistan called Borewala.  She is 52 years old and sells clothes to fulfill the basic needs of the family. She purchases clothes from Multan and Faisalabad and sells it at a profit in the different markets and clients of her city. She has been doing this business for the past 10 years and it has proved to be a profitable business for her. 

Her husband is a street hawker who sells different food items such as nimko & chips by visiting different communities on his bicycle. Salma's son who couldn’t get his education due to financial constraints. He learned the art of embroidery from his mother and now he operates his sewing and embroidery business simultaneously. He rents taking a shopt in the market. 

Salma has applied for a loan from Asasah for her cloth selling business. With the loan she will buy clothes in bulk and of different variety to minimize her cost of traveling and to offer more to her clients.  She is very confident that by making an  investment in her business she can improve her business condition.  She is in her third loan cycle and a responsible loan user with Asasah. In the previous two years loan experience she paid installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet R. is from the village of Duka, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 59 years old. Juliet is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling coconuts in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Juliet from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts to sell

loans.name: Samai

texts.en:
Mrs. Samai K. ( in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Sam-oeun K., live on an Island in the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1970 and have five sons and one daughter. 

Samai sells vegetables and meat in her village, while her husband sell mangoes, he buys mangoes on contract for the future season and when mangoes grow big enough he transports them to sell in the market located in Phnom Penh City.  

Samai has asked for a Kiva loan once before. She now is asking for her second loan of $1,000 to continue improving her husband's capital to purchase mangoes on contract for resale and to buy pesticide to prevent destruction of the mangoes by insects.

loans.use: To provide additional capital for her husband to purchase mangoes on contract for resale and to buy pesticide to prevent destruction of the mangoes by insects.

loans.name: Diosa

texts.en:
Diosa A. is from the village of Duka, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Diosa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Diosa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Diosa has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Diosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diosa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Diosa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marady

texts.en:
Mr. Marady M. ( in the photo), is 24 year-old and his wife, Mrs. Sreynet Kong, 22 years old, have been married since 2007 and have just had a young son. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Marady has been a driver for two years, while his wife is a garment factory worker. The couple spend a lot of money for traveling cost and do not have their own transportation for commuting. Marady decided to ask for his first loan in the amount of $500 purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Chheun

texts.en: Chheun N. is 30 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang Province. She sells various kinds of vegetables that she buys in bulk on credit from suppliers. Chheun N. sells her items in front of her home. In addition, she farms crops on her own farmland next to her house. Her husband sells ice-cream to pupils in school to raise extra money. The couple is married and have two school-age children. Chheun Vavy will use the loan she is requesting to repair her old house that often breaks down.

loans.use: To repair her old house that often breaks down.

loans.name: Waziran's Group

texts.en:
Waziran has spent her forty years of life in a city called Borewala. She moved here when she was a child. Borewala is a small city located in Pakistan.  She is a seam-stress who sews clothes for her neighborhood clients to supplement her income. Her husband is a painter who paints walls and buildings. He has more than twenty years of experience in this field.  He works on contracts basis and earns a  good income after completing the contrac. He provides his clients with quality work. 

Waziran is the mother of two daughters and two sons. Her eldest son is a bus conductor and the other one does embroidery works. Both of her sons left their education after 5th grade due to financial problems and started doing different work to financially support the family. Waziran’s daughters are in 8th and 6th grades respectively. 

She has applied for a loan for her husband for the second time from Asasah. With the loan he will buy paints of different colors and brands and offer quality work to his customers. She is very much confident that her husband will be able to improve his business condition with the help of this investment.

loans.use: Purchase paint boxes for paint business

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
