Mr. Leng C. (in the photo), is 60 years old and his wife Mrs. Pheun Phoung, 59 years old, have been married since 1971 and have five sons and one daughter. The family lives in a small village across Mekong River about 17 Kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple are old, but they are still strong workers.  

Leng is a plow builder and raises cows at home. His wife is a farmer. Leng is asking for his first loan in the amount of 500 USD to purchase additional cows to raise.

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca C. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Gingoog City. She is 53 years old. Rebecca is widowed and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rebecca owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp in the local community. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rebecca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fishes to sell. Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rebecca from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

location.town: Santa Cruz, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Torn

texts.en:
Mrs. Torn K. (pictured here), age 50, is a widow with one daughter. She lives along National Road Number five, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Her elderly mother and two nephews are living with her. 

Torn has been a garment factory worker for 20 years. Her nephew is a garment worker along with her. Torn does not have transportation for commuting and spends a lot of money on traveling costs. For this reason, she is applying for her a loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to get work.

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak G. is 24 years old and lives in Paravaqar village, Lievan area. Artak is married and lives with his wife, parents and little daughter. Artak is a military man and since 2006 he has been working in the Armenian army. At the same time Artak and his family are engaged in stock breeding and farming. Thanks to profits from their agricultural business, Artak has been able to meet his family needs, buy a car and repair his house.

Besides stock breeding Artak has decided to start a pig-breeding business, so he is asking from Kiva lenders, a 500.000 AMD loan to buy young pigs to realize his business idea.

loans.use: To buy young pigs to raise and breed

loans.name: Engelina

texts.en:
Engelina T. is from the village of Kandiis, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 27 years old. Engelina is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Engelina owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling broiler and native chickens in the local community. Engelina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Engelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Engelina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional chickens to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Engelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional chickens to sell

loans.name: Akber's Group

texts.en:
Akber lives in a small city called Borewala which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She has been living in this city with her family for over 20 years. She is 41 years old, a housewife and makes artificial flowers in her spare time to facilitate her husband financially. Her husband is involved in the spice selling business. He sells spices and also provides the services of blending spices for his customers by using a blender machine. Most of his customers come to him for blending their spices. He has been doing this work for over fifteen years.

Now his eldest son has also started this same business to help his family financially. He left his education after10th grade and started this business because his family needed his financial support. Akber’s youngest son is in sixth grade. She wants him to complete his education and become a doctor.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her eldest son. With the loan amount he will buy a blender machine and spices of different kinds and improve his business. Akber is in her 2nd loan cycle and has proved to be a very responsible loan user with Asasah. She has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: Purchase spices & blender machine

loans.name: Sam-Ul

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam-ul U. ( in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Chouheang Chum, live on an island in the Mekong River aboU. fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1979 and have 8 children-4 sons and 4 daughters. Three of them are married and live in separate homes. One is a security guard in Phnom Penh. Two children are in school and another one is a garment factory worker.  

Mrs. Sam-ul U. has been a silk weaver since 1996. Her husband is a farmer. He grows ginger and corn on his farmland in the village. She is requesting a loan of US$1,100 to pay school fees for her daughter and help provide capital for her husband's farming business.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her daughter and help [provide capital her husband's farming business.

loans.name: Asuncion

texts.en:
Asuncion L. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. She is 66 years old. Asuncion is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Asuncion owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Asuncion has been engaged in her business for over 50 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Asuncion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asuncion is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Asuncion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mabira Womens Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
50-year-old N. Hawa’s strong-hearted enterprise has been her springboard to the modest success she has been enjoying for the last fifteen years, plying her banana-selling business. In a month, she makes 160,000 shillings. Prior to this she was a farmer. She is a widow with six children.

In this kind of business where one has many competitors, treating customers with good grace is a virtue. One’s odds of success are increased when one strikes that nice impression with clients. This, in most cases, materializes into good rapport. This is exactly what Hawa can relate to as she has created for herself a dependable niche with this way of doing things.

Hawa began this business in Najjembe, Lugazi, with a loan from the then “Feed the Children, Uganda” and is now with Pearl Microfinance. With this loan, she wants to buy more bananas to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas to sell

loans.name: Sam-Onn

texts.en:
Miss. Sam-onn S., 22, is single and lives with her sisters and brothers and widower father along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Her father has diabetes.

Sam-onn has been a garment factory worker for two years. She is applying for $400 as her first loan to purchase a sewing machine for her sister, who is a tailor.

loans.use: To buy sewing machine for her sister

loans.name: Luyi

texts.en:
For some time, K. Luyi has been running multipurpose businesses that include agriculture and brick laying in Mbale, Ibanda. With good management and customer-care skills, these businesses generate him a good monthly profit.

With hard work, Luyi looks forward to improving his banana plantation through mulching and spraying the pests that are currently reducing his returns. This will definitely give his ventures a new lease for some time.

This loan will contribute on the purchase of pesticides and mulches so as to be able to get better yields. Luyi’s motive is to earn money to pay his children’s school fees and also to expand his businesses for more income.

loans.use: To buy mulches and pestcides for his banana plantation

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en: Pacita S. is from the village of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old, is single, and has two adult children. Pacita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Pacita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Phally

texts.en: Mrs. Phally S. is a widow with two daughters, both garment factory workers. She lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. In the photo, she is shown with her brother. Phally been a farmer, growing corn, since she was young. Besides farming, she also sells mangoes. Phally asked for a Kiva loan once before (click here to see her previous loan). She is now requesting $500 as her second loan to use for growing corn and to purchase additional corn on contract from the fellow villagers for resale.

loans.use: To use for growing corn and to purchase additional corn to sell

loans.name: Lubugumu Twekembe Group-Mukono

texts.en: The location is Namayuba trading center-Mukono. Thereby hangs a tale of a 35 year old woman-who, in a word, most people describe as exemplary, diligent, happy go lucky and a stickler for hard work. Such a description is only befitting of an individual who has, to all intents and purposes, made strides in whatever they do and who has struck a chord with people.  On 180,000 shillings as weekly profits, 35 year old B. Florence has secured her footing in her drug pharmacy business. This all boils down to her good human relationship skills and her suave business attitude. This mother of 4 set forth as a government employee prior to taking root in this business. She is requesting this loan to purchase more consignments of drugs for her pharmacy. In a broad sense, she sees her profits increasing with more sales of these drugs that she intends to buy.

loans.use: The purchase of more drugs for her pharmacy

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Miss. Sreymom P. (shown in the photo with her widowed mother), age 27, is a hairdresser and lives in a village along National Road Number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She is engaged and will get married soon.

Sreymon is asking for her first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a computer, printer and card pressing machine for her fiancé to operate his invitation publishing business.

loans.use: To purchase a computer, printer and card pressing machine for her fiancé to operate his invitation publishing.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita Y., age 58, and her husband Romeo have one child in college.  They work hard each day to cover daily expenses by running three businesses.  Rosita sells cosmetics and runs an e-loading station for cell phone users. Her husband drives a motorized tricycle.  Together the businesses generate PHP 7,000 a month.

Rosita has applied for a PHP 16,000 loan that she will use to purchase more Avon cosmetics products and to purchase more cell phone minutes for her e-loading station.  The additional supply will allow her to keep serving customers and should help increase her monthly earnings.  

Rosita has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since the beginning of 2010 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that someday earnings from her sales will allow her to own a bigger store and that her children will live happy and have successful lives.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: Replenish stock of Avon cosmetics products and to purchase more cell phone minutes for her e-loading station

loans.name: Fozia's Group

texts.en:
Fozia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. He is a painter and paints walls, windows and doors. He has been doing this business for over 10 years and Fozia is very confident that her husband will be able to successfully upgrade his business by buying paint boxes of different colors and brands for his business. 

She 42-year old woman who operates a quilt selling business. She buysquilts from the city of Lahore and sells to her community and also at the markets. The speciality of her quilts is that they are lite in weight but very warm. She earns approximately 5000 PKRs which she uses to pay for the education expenses of her daughters. She has given birth to two daughters and a three years old son. Both of her daughters are attending school and getting their education. 

She is a resident of a city of Borewala, a small city of Pakistan. She owns a three rooms house and has been living in it with her family for over twenty years.

loans.use: Purchase paint boxes for painting business

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen is married with four children and two of her children go to school.  She owns a food stall in  Namungoona  market. She sells food staffs like bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes and tomatoes.  She has been in this business for over five years. She buys her food supplies from Owino and Kasubi markets and uses public transport to and from shopping. She goes shopping three times a week.   Allen wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, bags of sweet and Irish potatoes and baskets of tomatoes.  

She sells to all categories of people and at retail only. Allen works seven days a week. Her business challenges are transportation of food stuffs from Owino to Kaw Namungoona  and seasonality.  She aspires to see her business grow big and start going directly to farmers for supplies.  She decided to work with MCDT because of the low interest charged.  Allen resides in and owns a two roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes  and tomatoes

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario T. has provided for her family by operating a sari-sari (variety) store for more than 12 years. Sari-sari stores basically sell small quantities of various foodstuffs, grocery items and beverages. “Sari” is a native word for variety. This is a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far away from the owner’s house. Such stores are convenient for people in the village who live far from the market place. The profit from this business has been the main source of family income. Now that Rosario has secured access to working capital, her profit is better than before. Rosario is now requesting another ASHI loan through Kiva for 35,000 PHP to purchase additional inventories of foodstuffs for her store. This will allow her to grow her business further so that she can support the educational needs of her six children until they complete college.

Rosario is hopeful that her sari-sari (variety) store will generate steady profits to improve her financial stability and give a better life for her family in a decent way. Rosario’s biggest dreams are to manage a full-fledged mini-grocery store someday and ensure the happiness of her family. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of her store is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and lift it out of poverty.

loans.use: To purchase the inventories of foodstuffs for her sari-sari (variety) store.

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Vong V. is a 37-year-old father of five teenage children, all of whom are in school. His wife raises poultry and grows rice. Since early 2005, Vong has made a living by both driving a taxi and working in construction, normally earning around $4 of income per day to support his family and buy them food. He will put his loan towards purchasing farm supplies for his wife to use on their farm field.

Note: Vong V.'s wife appears in the photograph

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Ernesta

texts.en:
Ernesta M., from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City, is 53 years old, married, and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Ernesta owns and operates a mini-restaurant serving a variety of meals to customers in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ernesta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant, Ernesta plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and drinks for her restaurant

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther, a single mother of three children who all attend school, has owned a stall in Bwaise selling second-hand clothes for ten years. Using public transport, she buys bales of used clothing from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Selling both retail and wholesale to all categories of people, Esther works six days a week and wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. Her business challenges are the transportation of clothing from Owino market to her stall in Bwaise and the rainy season because she works in an area prone to flooding.

Aspiring to import second-hand clothes herself, Esther decided to work with MCDT because of the low interest rates charged. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house, and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene A., from the village of San Miguel, Gingoog City, is 39 years old, widowed, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a business venture making and selling snacks and other delicacies such as steamed rice cakes in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, she is now requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP for the same purpose. This will be Arlene's second loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: San Miguel, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Elda

texts.en:
Elda C. is from the village of Ricoro in Gingoog City. She is 33 years old, is married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts within the local community. Elda has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for her retail activities.

In 2010 Elda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional coconuts to sell. Elda is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Elda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to poor households in Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Flor Hazel

texts.en:
Flor Hazel is a hardworking entrepreneur who is always looking for opportunities to grow. Through her daily effort, she is building a better future for her family. 

The fishing business has brought happiness to Flor Hazel’s family. Because of its profits, she has been able to support her family’s needs. Being a good mother, Flor has always wanted to support her children in whatever career they would be taking to better their own personal life. The fishing business is her way of saving money to support the needs of her family, especially to pay for her six children's education until college.

Her husband’s support of her fishing business is Flor Hazel’s motivation to continue expanding her business despite the trials of poverty. Over time, she has been able to purchase a fishing boat for her husband to manage and use for fishing. Meanwhile, Flor Hazel is the one who sells his fish directly to people in local community and nearby town of Tobias Fornier, Antique.

Flor Hazel is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase an additional fishing boat to catch more fish to sell. This would help their business grow, and make more profit, which will enable her to support her ambition in life.

loans.use: purchasing an additional fishing boat

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Determined Paul K., 54, is a happily married father of 7 children. Like any other responsible man he tried to find the best means to satisfy his family's requirements, having previously engaged in dairy farming.  

He went into the poultry farming business, where he looks after chickens for egg production and broilers for consumption, and this was done alongside his milk sales. In his home area of Rubumba, Rukungiri, he has a variety of chickens and this makes his business more attractive. With this project, he has been able to capture a good market from shopkeepers and hotel owners who purchase eggs that they prepare for customers. This has seen him earn 750,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

His main intention for taking up this loan is to help him purchase chicken feed and feeding troughs. This will improve his market supply and also his sales revenue collections as he looks at owning a hatchery project.

loans.use: purchasing chicken feed

loans.name: Elias

texts.en: Elias is 30 years old and married.  Elias is commonly known for selling a variety of goods in his shop.  Elias has been in this business for about four years and the hours of his business are from 7 am until late in the evening. After realizing that his capital is still too low to earn more profit, he would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Elias hopes that it will allow him to expand his sales as well as profits.  If successful, he will continue improving the living style of his family and in addition to that, he will expand his business for a better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for sale mainly foodstuffs such as rice, sugar, peas, etc

loans.name: Grecita

texts.en:
Grecita F. is from the village of Libon, Gingoog City. She is 54 years old. Grecita is married and has four adult children. Grecita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Grecita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Grecita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Grecita is requesting a  loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Grecita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: expanding store inventory; working capital

loans.name: Rogers

texts.en:
As they say that determination leads to destiny, Muhumuza Rogers is gaining momentum in his charcoal selling business in the R. Central market. Many people tend to undermine casual work here in Uganda but the 27 year old married father of 2 children has been able to earn a living through that business for over 6 years. 

Charcoal is commonly used here in Uganda as a form of energy in many homes to cook food and for house warming in cold places, as prices for paraffin, gas and electricity are always high. Through selling charcoal he is able to earn 323,000 Ugandan shillings monthly, although there are drawbacks like transporting his products to bigger markets such as Kampala city. 

With this loan, he hopes to expand into bigger markets and supply larger charcoal markets. This will help in improving his sales revenue to meet his family’s needs.

loans.use: purchasing charcoal for business expansion

loans.name: Vumiriya

texts.en:
Vumiriya is married and has three children who are all at school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a bar in Mengo Mackay selling all types of drinks ranging from crude local gin to beer and local brew. She has been in this business for over ten years. She sells to all categories of people both at retail and wholesale.  

She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and jeryrcans of local brew and gin. Vumiriya works from her home and so doesn’t rent the business premises.  She buys crates of beer from delivery vans and jerrycans of local gin from suppliers who get them from the Kasese district in southwestern Uganda.  She works seven days a week. 

Her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She is aspires to selling at wholesale only. She decided to join MCDT because she wanted additional capital.  Vumiriya resides in and rents a two roomed house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: buying beer and local gin

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan S. has been spending her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is the mother of a daughter who is already married and lives at home. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual operation with which she has had great success. 

Chan S.’s daughter proposes to work as a laborer outside of the country through a private company but she needs to pay the service fee. Because she doesn’t have money, Chan S. decided to take out a loan to meet the requirement above. Any remaining cash, she will use towards growing rice crops.

loans.use: paying job placement fee; supporting farm

loans.name: Moaen

texts.en:
Mouin is a 43 years old divorced man from Lebanon. He has owned a small fuel station for the last 17 years.  Mouin sells tires and engine oil, and also washes cars. His clients are of various kinds: neighbors, relatives, and those passing by. His business is located in a very special spot that everyone can recognize. His diversity in his work helps in the non-stop work cycle, which is a blessing in itself. 

This is Mouin’s first loan request from Al Majmoua, in order to buy extra tires and lubricant oils as requested by his clients. Mouin finds it hard when clients pass by requesting a certain product that he doesn’t have; he states that this thing may lead his clients to another source, which will have a bad effect on his business. Mouin hopes to own a big station with a professional car wash, oil change, and maintenance department.

loans.use: buying tires and oil

loans.name: So

texts.en: So B. is 29 years of age and a married woman. In order to meet the needs of the family, So B. sells a little grocery inventory out of her home. She has been in this business for two years. To help contribute to the family, her husband works as a building laborer for a small firm. So B. and her husband have been married for years and they have two young children who attend school. She hopes to enlarge her business and is applying for a $500 US loan to be used to accumulate a larger number of necessary grocery items to sell.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: 03.11.22.dien Bien Group

texts.en:
L. T. Hop (111) is a 32 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Hop is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 22.Dien Bien (03.11.22.Dien Bien).

Hop is married and has 2 school-aged children.  Hop owns & operates a business providing general services to local community members.  Hop has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Hop joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Hop has successfully repaid her first loan, for 4,248,000 Vietnamese dong (VND), from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This first loan was used to expand the business.  She is now requesting her second loan, for 5,310,000 VND, which will again be used to expand the business.   Hop plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve and expand it.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  L. T. Ly (109) is a 68 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.
2.  N. T. Thao (110) is a 37 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a tailoring business.
3.  L. T. Lien (112) is a 31 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a tailoring business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Hop L. Hop (111) là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Hop là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 22.Dien Bien (03.11.22.Dien Bien).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Hop thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hop kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Hop đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hop đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.248.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Ly (109) là 68 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


2.  N. T. Thao (110) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc.


3.  L. T. Lien (112) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: expanding services business

loans.name: Dancilla

texts.en:
Dancilla is 36 years old and married with three children who are 7, 11 and 15 years old.  Dancilla is in the business of selling meat. Her business hours are from 7 am to 7 pm every day.  Dancilla has been in this business for about seven years.

Dancilla would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, she will try to increase the sales of meat so that her profits can increase.  If these profits are increased as expected, Dancilla will create some other sources of income and in addition to that, she will improve the living style of her family and start saving for a better future.

loans.use: To buy additional meat for sale

loans.name: Ngarama Farmers Women, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
They say that hard work pays, and a very determined K. Stella has gained from the fruits of hard work, having started her hotel enterprise over 20 years ago; she has no regrets. She provides lodging and accommodation services in Kambuga trading centre of Kihihi.

Due to the good management and esteemed customer care, the business has maintained customers for a long time, thus creating the good hotel market as they maintain high levels of hygiene. With this loan, Stella wants to renovate the lodges put in place good furniture, and also go shopping for hotel equipment as the existing equipment is out dated. This will enable her to get more customers, earn more profit, and meet her family and children’s requirements (such as education). She is very optimistic about achieving a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: renovating lodges

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Yorn Y. is a 35-year-old married man and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Phnom Penh. Yorn Y. owns a piece of farmland that he bought many years ago from his nearby neighbor. He uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. He has a life partner in his wife who appears in the photograph and earns a living selling vegetables. Yorn Y. planted rice crops two months ago, but his crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, he would like a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer. Yorn Y. intends to use any remaining money from the loan to accrue capital for his wife's business.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of fertilizer.

loans.name: Milton

texts.en:
Operating a retail shop selling general merchandise is a formidable business venture from which M. Milton, aged 31, has managed to earn some money to fulfill his life and his family's necessities up until now in Omuruberera Trading Centre, Rukungiri. 

It is difficult for many youth in this area to settle down and create their own means of earning; many spend their time drinking alcohol and gambling. Milton has a different economic approach and has the responsibility of taking care of his 3 children and family, which has made him selttle down with his business.

Having received little capital from his previous farming business, to kick start his retail shop business that should make him 350,000 UGX monthly, he is seeking a loan to expand his business into wholesale and purchase enough stock as there is a ready market of customers. He is looking at buying a plot of land when he gets more money.

loans.use: To purchase more stock.

loans.name: Corona

texts.en:
Corona T. is a busy entrepreneur managing her fishing business. Her previous loan from ASHI has provided working capital to expand her business and purchase additional fishing materials. With the loan, Corona has noticed that her monthly income has almost doubled since she has attracted new customers with additional inventory of fish.

Corona joined Kiva partner ASHI in 2003 attracted by ASHI's low interest rates and range of loans for business, education, and home repair. Prior to ASHI, Corona had no access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Positive growth from her business has helped Corona fund the education of her children. Since joining ASHI, Corona has experienced positive changes in her life. She hopes her fishing business will continue to flourish so she can provide long term financial stability for her family.

The fishing business also contributes income for them and that’s why, even if sometimes selling fish is hard to do, Corona never gets tired of doing it. Therefore, she is now requesting another loan for a larger amount of 24,000 PHP to purchase additional fish nets and support maintenance of their boat pump. This will allow her to grow their business further so that their children fulfill their dreams and experience a life that’s full of happiness. She continues to pray and wishes all lenders all the best and good luck and hopes they will will continue to support poor families like hers who want to improve their standards of living.

Her long term goals are to help support her children's education, invest and build a better house for the family and to have a full-fledge fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish nets and support maintenance of their boat pump.

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en: Oeun Y. is a domestic farmer who plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $2.5 per day. Her husband also goes to work in the field with her. This couple is married but does not have any children yet. Oeun Y. lacks funds to support her in her farm trade so she would like to seek a Kiva loan in the amount of US$400 in order to buy fertilizer, insecticide, a pump, and seed for planting.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, a pump, and seed for planting.

loans.name: Hanifan's Group

texts.en:
Hanifan lives in a small city called Borewala in Pakistan.

She is a very talented lady. She makes embroidered dresses to supplement her household income. She collects orders from her neighborhood clients and fulfills them on time. Her earning allows her to pay for the utilities. Her husband runs a small business in the market where he offers different kinds of food such as Nan chanay and Biryani and tea to his customers. 

Hanifan lives with her in-laws. Her mother-in-law is a very active elderly lady and makes bread. Hanifan has given birth to a son and a daughter who are studying in 9th and 6th standard respectively.

She has applied for a loan for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, he will buy required items such as lentils, cooking oil, rice and spices for his business. 

Hanifan has a good reputation in her family and is known as a 'helpful woman' because of her helpful nature; she is always ready to support her family in every possible way. 

She is hopeful that with the loan amount, her husband’s business conditions will get better and her family will be able to enjoy better standard of living. She is in her 2nd loan cycle and is a very responsible Asasah loan user. She has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To purchase required items for her husband's business.

loans.name: Zikusooka Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
By and large, the last 3 years have seen 60 year old N. Christine succeed in making profitable use of the relative short time that she has been at the helm of her fish sales business in Nkokonjeru-Lugazi. She has used her down the line sense of determination to make the progress she only envisaged at the beginning. She was prevailed upon by her husband to begin this business. She supplies the profit deficiencies in her fish sales business with modest additional profits from a firewood sales business. 

Christine is a good humored, married woman with 5 children. In a month, she makes as much as 900,000 shillings and, with this loan, she is anticipating revamping her business. She specifically wants to buy more firewood to sell.

loans.use: The purchase of more fire wood to sell.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene A. N. is twenty eight years old, married and has one child, aged five years old. Her business is located at Mtopanga tushikane estate in Mombasa,Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites, including the Indian ocean's white sand beaches. 

She has been selling fruits and vegetables for the past six months to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is weather conditions, in relation to where her business is located. During rainy seasons it becomes too hard for customers to access her business and during the dry seasons it becomes too dusty. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well and also providing good customer service to grow her business. She is using her loan of KES40,000 to buy more fruits and vegetables to expand her business. She hopes to be a supplier of groceries and to diversify to selling eggs in the future. She also hopes to provide employment to other people and to give her child a quality education some day. She describes herself as very outgoing.

loans.use: Vegetables and fruits sales.

loans.name: Ping's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has four members who live in Preak Be village, Kandal province. Mrs. Ping H. is a group leader who was born in 1957. She was selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to support their businesses. 

She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family, while her husband, Mr. Keng Yen, is a laborer. Her problem is that her home is too old to live in. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Ping H. is applying for a loan to fix her own home. She is the mother of a child who is a support taxi driver.

loans.use: To fix her own home

loans.name: Iringo Twebiseho, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
It is now 16 years since N. Grace started up his farming business adventure in Kikuuto, Ntungamo. The married mother of 3 children is very aggressive and determined when it comes to lucrative business. She has since engaged herself in various farming practices, including banana growing, which is her main source of livelihood alongside growing coffee and her teaching profession. 

N. Grace's main drawbacks include the bad weather conditions, like drought, which reduces the rate of production in terms of poor quality and also the fluctuating prices. With this loan she is looking forward to purchasing more farm inputs to improve on production. Grace is very optimistic about producing more harvests and increasing sales revenue. With these improvements, she will be able to look after her family and pay for the education of her children.

loans.use: Towards purchase of farm inputs for increased crop production.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Mr. Suon C. is highly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He has a few physical laborers to help provide his service. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He has another partner in his wife, who sells grocery inventories from home. Suon C. has two children who are students and dependent upon him. Suon C. sees that selling groceries is a profitable business for his family and he hopes to expand this activity. Thus, he is requesting this loan for his wife to accumulate a large quantity of inventory for their grocery store.

loans.use: To accumulate a large quantity of inventory for grocery store.

loans.name: Hima Agahikaine Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
K. Bonefance, aged 43, is married and has a family of 4 children. He has been operating a retail shop from Munobwa trading centre, Kyenjojo for over 10 years. In his business, he trades in a variety of products such as commonly used household items like sugar, salt, soft drinks, sodas, water, cooking oil and much more general merchandise. He does this business alongside his other farming practices that include growing a variety of food crops in Uganda. His main drawback is that he has a limited variety of products in his shop. He find that his current stock cannot satisfy the customers demands. Therefore he is looking forward to increase stock in his business, when he gets this loan, and also to expand into a wholesale shop. This will help him earn more revenue and to sustain his daily life needs and to further the educate of his children. 

K. Bonefance belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stock like sugar, salt, soft drinks like sodas, water, cooking oil and much more for resale.

loans.name: Khaem

texts.en:
Mr. Khaem T., a villager in Preak Ta Thok village, Kandal Province, and his wife, Mrs. Sok Thet, own a one-hectare plot of land upon which they grow rice to support their family. Khaem is also a motorbike taxi driver. Because his rice field is infertile, he is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer.

Khaem is the father of four children, one a seamstress in a garment factory, another a student, and the others yet too young to study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Ziyaddin

texts.ru:
Ziyaddin A. 26 let. On ne jinat. Ziyaddin yavlyayetsya IDP personom ,on pereselenec iz qoroda Fuzuli oblast Dilegerde, seychas on projivayet v Absheron regione.

Ziyaddin uje 3 qoda yavlyayetsya masterom pompovoqo nasosa. On provodit zalivku betona  na krishi damov pri stroykax. Ziyaddin etomu biznesu nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca on toje bil masterom pompovoqo nasosa. Seychas Ziyaddin nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit zapchasti i zamenit dviqatel pompovoqo aparata. Vsya eqo rabota zavisit ot aparata poetomu on xochet pochenit eqo.
texts.en:
Ziyaddin A. is 26 years old. He is single. He is an Internally Displaced Person, displaced from the town of Fuzuli in the Dilegerde Region. Now he lives in the Absheron Region. For the last three years he has been working as a cement pump operator. He uses the pump to convey cement to the roofs of buildings under construction. Ziyaddin has learned his trade from his father, who was also a cement pump operator. At present Ziyaddin needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to buy spare parts and replace the engine. His work wholly depends on his equipment, and therefore he would like to get it repaired.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts and replacing the engine

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is a resident of Borewala, a city which is located in south Punjab, Pakistan. She is a middle-aged woman who embroiders clothes for her nearby clients to earn an income. She is famous in her area for her quality work and gets a good amount of orders every month. The income she earns helps her to pay for the education expenses of her daughter. She is the mother of a son and a daughter. Her daughter is in 8th grade, while her son is 5 years of age and has not yet started going to school.

Her husband runs a grocery shop in a market, where he sells regularly used groceries, specifically rice, spices, and cooking oil. His shop is located in a place where he faces crowds of people every day. To fulfill the needs of the people and increase his customer base, he has to maintain his stock of groceries. But, currently, he doesn’t have enough stock, and due to this he is going to lose his customers day by day, which is not good for his business. Therefore, Yasmeen has decided to acquire a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. The loan will help her husband buy the required groceries for his shop and overcome the business problems as well. She is very hopeful that her husband will once again bring his business to the top by increasing his profit.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mrs. Uk C. is a 46-year-old married woman and a humble villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kampong Chhnang Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she bought many years ago from a nearby villager. She uses her own land to grow different kinds of crops. She has a life supporter in her husband, who assists her with the farm work. In addition to her farm job, Uk C. works making clay stoves from home. She also receives help producing stoves from her school-age kids when they are free from studying. Uk C. is taking this loan to purchase raw material to make stoves so she can sell them to raise income. Mrs. Uk C. was not available for the photo, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase raw material to make stoves

loans.name: Ma. Amy

texts.en:
Ma. Amy B. is a woman with big dreams and the bravery to fight challenges in order to achieve her dreams. She is 40 years old and married to Roderick, 46, who is a fisherman. She is a caring mother to six children who are all minors. She lives in the town of Laua-an, Antique Province, in the Philippines.

She joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, for the opportunity of having start-up capital for generating income. With her previous loan from ASHI, she carefully invested in her hog-raising business, and it gave her a reasonable income. Now on her second loan, she requests 10,000 PHP to continue raising hogs and to support her second venture—a fishing business. Specifically, the loan will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed, and the remaining money will be used to pay for a fishing boat for her fishing business. This loan will help expand her businesses.

As a mother, Ma. Amy dreams of sending her children to school and on to complete college degrees so they can find jobs for a better living. She hopes that her business will expand for them so they will have savings for future use. She also enjoys seeing that the loan from ASHI will change their lives and accommodate her family's needs. Through the support of Kiva partner ASHI, she will, step-by-step, realize her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and feed, and to pay for a fishing boat for her fishing business

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim L. is a 49-year-old woman, married to Em Ros, aged 48. They have two school-aged children and earn a living by planting various crops on their own farmland. Kim L. currently plants a rice crop, which she will harvest and sell when it is mature. Recently, her crop is not growing well because it may require fertilizer. Because of that, Kim L. has decided to seek a loan to buy fertilizer, which she will use to fatten her crop yield.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, which she will use to fatten her crop yield.

loans.name: Elchin

texts.ru:
Elchin M. 39 let. Elchin Jenat i imeyet odnovo sina ktoromu 10 let on uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya sportom. Elchin yavlyayetsya IDP personom , on pereselenec iz Fuzuli, Seychas on projivayet v Fuzuli regione  derevnya Ahmedbeyli.

Elchin uje 7 let rabotayet taksistom. Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u starsheqo brata i nachal on bizness po eqo sovetu, no v toje vremya on ochen polubit etu rabotu. Elchin seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit zapchasti dlya eqo taksi kotoriy isportilsya.
texts.en:
Elchin M. is 39 years old. Elchin is married and has a ten-year-old son who goes to school and plays sports. Elchin is an IDP (internally displaced person); he is a refugee from Fuzuli. Currently, he lives in the Fuzuli region in the village of Ahmedbeyli. Elchin has been driving a taxi for seven years. His older brother taught him the business and he began it with his brother’s advice. At the same time, he truly loves his work. Elchin currently needs 2000 AZN to buy parts to repair his taxi.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying car parts

loans.name: Luong's Group

texts.en:
Luong T. H. D. is 37 years old and lives in Ngoc Loi hamlet, Duc Tu commune. She is married with two children and her husband is a carpenter. Her family has a carpentry workshop and she and her husband work there producing wooden furniture. They have a monthly income of about 4,500,000 VND.

Mrs Luong is the leader of this five-member group loan from SEDA. For her previous loan, she borrowed 4,578,000 VND and has repaid this amount completely and punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND in order to buy more wood.

About the other borrowers in the group:

Van T. T. is 57 years old and would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND in order to buy wood.

Duyen T. D. is 31 years old and would like to borrow 5,886,000 VND in order to expand her carpentry workshop.

Mai T. N. is 27 years old and has a store. She would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to expand her store.

Bich T. L. is 46 years old and sells pork in the market. She would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND for her business.

loans.use: To buy more wood to make more furniture

loans.name: Melowgen

texts.en: Melowgen is 44 years old, married, and lives in the province of Antique in the Philippines with her husband and two children. To make a better living, Melowgen sells gasoline and gas from her house. She has been a busy entrepreneur for almost two years. Melowgen would like a loan to purchase gallons of gasoline and gas amounting 10,000 PHP. Melowgen is grateful for the secure access to capital and loans to fund her entrepreneurial dreams. Her long-term goals are to expand her business, support her family financially, and fund the college education of her two children through college. With the support of Kiva lenders and her own entrepreneurial effort, she is focused on building a winning business.

loans.use: To purchase gallons of gasoline and gas.

loans.name: Ha's Group

texts.en:
Ha T. D. is 23 years old and is married with two children. She lives in Thac Qua hamlet, Duc Tu commune. She has a store and has this job for many years. She has a monthly income of about 5,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).

Ha T. D. is the leader of this six-member group loan from SEDA. For her last loan, she borrowed 2,436,000 VND and has repaid it completely and punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to expand her store.

About the other borrowers in the group:

Tuyet T. N. is 34 years old. She makes tofu and would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to buy beans.

Thu T. D. is 40 years old and would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to breed pigs.

Van T. N. is 53 years old and would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to breed poultry.

Bac K. N. is 42 years old and he would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND in order to raise chickens.

Thuy T. P. is 22 years old. She is a tailor and would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy cloth.

loans.use: To expand her store

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en: Carolyne M. is twenty years old and married with four children to whom she hopes to give a quality education. She lives in Kakamega and owns a general store at her home where she has been selling such items as sugar, cooking fat, flour, detergents, soft drinks, and paraffin for the last five years. She says that this business is profitable, but her major challenge is customers not paying their debts, therefore reducing her profit. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to expand her business. She hopes to move to a busy trading area where she can get more customers. She describes herself as focussed.

loans.use: to buy sugar, cooking fat, paraffin, flour etc

loans.name: Amil

texts.ru:
Amil M. 21 let. On ne jinat . Amil jivet v Absheron regione v poselke Bine. Amil uje 2 qoda nachal zanimatsya etim biznesom prodaji naskov optavuyu. 

Nachat etot biznes emu pomoq brat starshiy kotoriy i nauchil eqo etomu delu. Seychas Amil nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi uvelichit pomesheniye tak kak on prodayet v optavuyu yemu nujno mnoqo mestno. Amil  xotelbi v budushem v svoyom maqazine prodovat i druqiye tovari v optavuyu.
texts.en:
Amil M. is 21 years old. He is single. Amil lives in the Absheron region in the village of Bila. Two years ago, Amil started his business of selling socks wholesale. His older brother helped his start this business and taught him this work. Currently, Amil needs 2000 AZN to expand his space. Since he sells wholesale, he needs a lot of room. In the future, Amil would like to sell other goods wholesale in his shop.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing the size of the shop

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en: Jesca is a single mother of four children and all her children go school. She also takes care of her old parents. She owns a stall in Bwaise selling second-hand clothes which she buys from Owino market — one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Jesca uses public transportation for shopping trips which she makes once a week.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She has been in the clothing business for many years. She also gets additional income from knitting table clothes. She sells to all categories of people but mainly women and girls. Her business challenges include  seasonality and transportation of bales of clothes from Owino Market to Bwaise.  She hopes to see her business grow big and start importing clothes and later selling wholesale only. Jesca joined MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. She lives in, and owns, a three-roomed house. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. When she received her previous loans, she invested the money in a hog-raising business and later expanded the business with more pigs. For supplementary income, she has also embarked on an electronic loading business for cell phones such as Smart load, Globe load, and Sun load.

Now on her second loan, she has requested 10,000 PHP as additional working capital for her E-load business and the maintenance of her hog-raising business. She is positive that her businesses will grow since she already has regular customers buying her pigs after four months and solid clients for her E-loading business at home.

She dreams of having a pig farm someday and to provide satisfactory E-loading to her customers. She hopes to have successful businesses that can provide her with a good life and enable her to move beyond the poverty line. She is grateful to ASHI for offering her happiness in life and group support in achieving her goals.

Carmelita’s long term goals are to build sustainable businesses and to fund her three children’s college education. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her businesses will generate a steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her E-load and hog-raising businesses.

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en:
Hajara owns a stall in Kalerwe market, selling bananas. She buys bunches of bananas from villages in Masaka District and uses public transport to and from making these purchases. She would like to use this loan of 1,000,000 to buy more bunches of bananas. In addition to her banana vending business, Hajara also owns motorcycles for hire and offers rental rooms. 

Hajara sells her wares to all categories of people, both in retail and wholesale. She works six days a week and makes her purchases once a week. Her business challenges include problematic transportation and dealing with the rainy season, which often makes village roads impassable. She hopes one day to own a delivery van.  

Hajara and her husband, who works as a spare parts dealer, have five children, all of whom attend school. She also takes care of her elderly parents. They live in a four-roomed house. The family has access to electricity but has no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, medications, and food. She aspires toward educating her children to university level. 

She decided to work with MCDT because of the low interest charged.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en: Bassam is a 26 year old single man from Lebanon, owner of a grocery store since 2009. Bassam is requesting a Loan from Al Majmoua for the first time in order to buy products that are not currently carried in his shop. He also wants to buy a backup  generator because he has to keep his fridges running 24/7 to keep his products fresh. Bassam helps contribute to his family's income. He hopes to open a big market in the future. He believes he can be successful since he is active and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy products not currently carried in his shop

loans.name: Abasse

texts.en: As a 20 year old single man, it’s hard to find a more ambitious man than Abbasse. Abbasse opened an accessories and makeup shop which is rare in his area. His shop is very attractive to the girls in his region. Abbasse was very smart in choosing this kind of work since his customers are passing tourists, ladies and teenagers living in or visiting the area. Abbasse's family has given him moral support to pursue this business. He carries accessories, makeup, perfumes, teddy bears and gadgets, which has turned his shop into a kind of a gift shop for targeted customers. This is Abbasse’s first request for a loan from Al Majmoua.  He will use it to buy extra products for his shop to keep it up to date with the market. Abbasse hopes one day to wholesale his inventory to cover a wider region.

loans.use: To buy extra products to his shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more stationery materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more footwear to sell.

loans.name: Xalil

texts.ru:
Xalil Xalilovu 24 let. Xalil ne jenat on jivet v Absheron regione. Xalil s detstva pomoqal svoyemu otcu v eqo rabote. Etomu biznesu eqo toje nauchil eqo otec. Xalil uje 4 qoda otkril etot maqazin po sovetu otca. 

Seychas Xalil nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit noviye tipi materialov dlya prodaji. Ranshe Xalil prodoval materiali dlya sshitya odejdi , podushki  i t.d a seychas on xochet kupit tkani dlya zanavesok.
texts.en:
Xalil X. is 24 years old. He is single and lives in the Absheron region. Since he was a child, Xalil has helped his father with work. His father started this business. Four years ago, Xalil opened this store under his father. Currently, Xalil needs 2000 AZN to buy new types of fabric to sell. Before, Xalil sold fabric for sewing clothes, pillows, etc. Now, he wants to buy fabric for drapes.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying new fabric

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: Fatmata B. I. is married to a driver and has 2 dependents.  She sells materials for different types of sport in the central market of Makeni city. Fatmata has 25 years of experience in her sporting goods business, which was initially financed by her husband. Fatmata has a good loan repayment history.  She needs a loan of 3,000,000 SLL to buy more items for her shop and hopes to use the proceeds of her loan to educate her children and to buy a  piece of land.

loans.use: To buy more items for her shop.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 45 years old married man father of four children, living in Chtaura Lebanon; He has been an owner of a spare parts shop since 1985. This is a very well known business in Chtaura as most of its population work in the automobile business. Ibrahim buys old cars or others that were sold after an accident, in order to be dismantled into useful parts, to be sold as spare parts. In addition to used spare parts, Ibrahim sells new spare parts too, which is a positive point for him among competitors. His clients can be anyone with a car problem and also other mechanics who buy his new and used spare parts.. This is the first time Ibrahim has requested a loan from Al Majmoua  in order to buy more new and used spare parts that will help expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more new and used spare parts

loans.name: Elias

texts.en: Elias N. is 39 years old and owner of a butchery business in Kisimani, Mombasa. Elias is single and has been in the business for nineteen years. His main clients are residents of Kisimani in Mombasa, Kenya.  This is Elias's  second loan. With this loan, he would like to expand his butchery business by increasing the variety of meat he sells. Elias wants to open up a new butchery with the anticipated profits and expand it in the future.

loans.use: To expand his butchery business and increase the variety of meat he sells

loans.name: Benny

texts.en:
Benny N. is a widow with no children. She takes care of additional family members.  Benny resides in and owns a four room house. The family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses are for school fees, medication, food and utility bills.  

Benny is tailor/ designer on Luwum Street in Kampala City, Uganda. She designs and makes all types of fashions for women. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale.  At times she goes door to door selling her clothes. Benny works six days a week.  Her business challenges are the rainy season and defaulters. She wants to use this loan of 700000 UGX to buy more clothing materials, thread and zippers.  Benny aspires to buy a plot of land so that she can have her own business premises and also have a bridal shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothing material, thread and zippers

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes O. is 44 years old.  She is married and blessed with three children. She has been a second hand clothes dealer in Magongo, Mombasa, Kenya  for three years. Agnes' business is successful and she is now borrowing her second loan from KADET. She plans to increase the stock of  second hand clothes in order to satisfy her clientele most of whom are residents and friends. Agnes hopes to expand her clothes business to other Mombasa locations.

loans.use: To increase the stock of second hand clothes

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. is twenty five years old. She is a single mother of a five year old child. Esther owns a cereals retail shop in Mshomoroni, Mombasa, Kenya.

Esther  has been in the cereals business for one year and her business is doing well. This is her first loan from KADET. Esther would like to use the funds to purchase more stock of cereals and to carry out the  renovation of her shop. She will use the anticipated profit to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of cereals and to renovate her shop

loans.name: Jariatu

texts.en:
Jariatu sells plastic and rubber utensils and set-pans in the Silvanus market. The market is located in the Gbaneh section of the city of Makeni. Jariatu works hard. She opens her business at 7 a.m. and closes up shop at 6 p.m. 

Jariatu is married to an active trader and they have four dependents. She has seven years of experience in her business. 

She needs a loan of 4,000,000 in order to buy more stock from Conakry. She wishes to use the proceeds buy a piece of land and to pay for the education of her children.

loans.use: To buy more plastic and rubber utensils to sell in her market stall

loans.name: Monday

texts.en: Monday R. is currently in the business of selling ice cream, bread and groundnut paste at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bread to sell. Monday is 39 years old and is married, with a husband who is a builder. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock more bread to sell

loans.name: Jemila

texts.en: Jemila A. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables such as cabbages, dodo (plantain), okra and tomatoes at the market, and is requesting a loan to stock fruits such as oranges, guava, etc. to sell. Jemila is 45 years old and is married, with a husband who is an electrician. She has four children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop.

loans.use: To stock fruits such as oranges, guava, etc. to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane A. is currently in the business of selling fresh sweet potatoes, Irish potatoes and cassava imported from Uganda, and is requesting a loan to stock more cassava to sell. Jane is 41 years old and is married, with a husband who is a peasant. She has four children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to stock bags of maize and sorghum in order to increase her profits.

loans.use: To stock maize and sorghum to sell

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en: Kasifa is married with five children, four of whom go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. Kasifa owns a retail shop in Natete selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, dry cells and exercise books. She buys her merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala city and uses public transport to and from shopping, which she does once a week. She has been in this business for four years. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of soap, cartons of salt, and cooking oil. Besides this retail shop business she sells secondhand women's clothes and piped water to earn additional income. She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and the rainy season. Her major customers are taxi touts because she works near Natete taxi park. She aspires to build her own house. She decided to work with MCDT because they are trustworthy and she needed additional capital. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, food and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil

loans.name: Simar

texts.en: Simar Martinal is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant. Simar is 42 years old and is married, with a husband who is a business man. She has five children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: To stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant

loans.name: Christian

texts.en:
Christian L. is a vendor of pumpkins, pumpkin leaves, okra, and dodo at market. She wishes to expand her offerings and and is therefore requesting a loan to stock other fruits, such as gavva and oranges. 

Christian is 21 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. They have two children, the elder of whom attends school. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes eventually to be able to open up and operate a bar.

loans.use: To stock additional fruits such as gavva and oranges for sale

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is a vegetable and fruit vendor. She owns a stall at Nakawa market in the city suburbs where she sells her wares. She buys her fruits and vegetables from the very market where she works and therefore does not incur any transport costs during purchasing. She has been in this business for ten years. In addition to her market stall, she owns a small retail shop at her home which brings in some additional income.

She sells her wares at retail prices and works seven days a week. Her business challenges are seasonality and defaulters. She aspires toward a business model where she would eventually sell her wares directly to farmers. She also hopes someday to build her own house. 

She decided to join MCDT because they were giving out timely loans at low interest. She would like to use this loan of 800,000 to buy more baskets of mangoes, oranges, pineapples, cabbages, and yellow bananas.  

Edith resides in a rented two-roomed house with her husband and six children. All their children attend school. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of mangoes, oranges, cabbages, pineapples, and yellow bananas to sell

loans.name: Lulia
